Content.name: Chloe Visits The Laundress Office
Recipe for Seasonal Storage
Content.description:
Wash and clean everything! Have you ever thought, "It doesn't look dirty"..."I don't see any spots"..."I think I only wore it once and it was just a short time." JUST WASH IT. Why? Ever wonder where that big yellow spot came from? Perfume, body products, body oil, food and dirt show up later and are much harder to get out. This also is true for starch. Do not store items that are starched. All of the above are the feeding ground for bugs.

 

Tools:

All-Purpose Storage Bag, Hotel Laundry Bag, Under Bed Storage Bag, Lavender Scented Sachets, Wool & Cashmere Spray, Stain Solution, Stain Brush, Beckel Storage Cubes, Scented Vinegar, Detergent

Seasonally Re-organize:

If you don't store items seasonally, you should do a thorough re-organization once or twice a year. Clean your wardrobe and drawers for the new season - take everything out, wash, vacuum & re-organize your drawers.

Proper Storage:

We recommend storing items clean (obviously) and folded well. Delicate items and items prone to wrinkling are best when folded with acid free tissue. (Acid free tissue is very important for long term storing - not as important for short term i.e. season to season). Do not hang knits, silks, and synthetics as you may not recognize it or it may not fit the next season. Fur, leather and outerwear are best stored hung - if these items are not stored properly, they can lose their natural oils by drying out which are the luxurious properties. Pack clothes and textiles in a breathable fabric, such as cotton or linen, and with a zipper closure. The Laundress All-Purpose Storage Bag is designed for larger items, the Beckel Storage Cubes come in a variety of sizes to accommodate all your items, big and small. Never store in plastic or cardboard. Plastic bins, cardboard, and dry cleaner bags may look tidy, but are not suitable for good textile storage as they attract and encourage bugs and bug reproduction. Do not use drawer liners or contact paper as the adhesive can attract bugs as well.

Where to Store:

Items should be stored in a clean, cool, dark and dry area. Where is this? Not usually in an attic or basement as humid/damp areas such an attic or basement are optimal environments for moth breeding attacks, mold and mildew. Extreme temperatures will damage textiles and direct sunlight will fade and deteriorate fabrics as well. *Pulling out vintage items from storage? Click here for our antique/vintage washing recipe.

Mold/Mildew Problems:

Do you have water damage or flooding from all the storms this winter? Unfortunate circumstances can cause unfortunate problems. Not to worry though, with some patience, items with mold and mildew usually can be salvaged. Treating cotton and linens are the easiest to treat - click here for our recipe. For washing wools, treat with our Stain Solution and soak in water with 1 cup of The Laundress Scented Vinegar. The same should be done for silks. Soak items until stains, mold, mildew are removed. The Laundress Stain Brush is very helpful for scrubbing the area gently. Once satisfied, proceed with normal laundering.

Silverfish, Moth, Bug Issues:

There are non-toxic moth products out there, avoid moth balls - which are toxic and deadly - and impossible to remove their odor. We do not recommend cedar wood blocks or chips. If you are using cedar wood avoid direct contact with the textiles as they can transfer oil to fabric which will create stains and are hard to remove. Cleaning and storing properly is a great start. Use The Laundress Natural Lavender Scented Sachets or The Laundress Wool & Cashmere Spray which are natural moth and bug repellants. If you've been attacked by moths, quarantine the scene!The freezer is a good holding spot with air tight bags (throw away after) while you wash everything such as clothes & drawers in the exposed areas. It is imperative to clean your machine* after. Do not go to the dry-cleaner or laundromat as you will infest other clothing and the location. Click here for other moth tips. *Clean your washer monthly - fill the dispensers with Scented Vinegar and sprinkle All-Purpose Bleach Alternative into the bleach dispenser and run a lengthy, empty load with hot water.

Content.name: The Laundress Recipe Essentials
Content.description:
A good grasp of the essentials makes your regular laundry tasks simpler and more enjoyable! Using the proper detergent at the correct water temperature and with just the right amount of agitation - and knowing when and how to pre-treat for stains - are the marks of a truly savvy laundress.

 

For specific instructions, always refer to the garment's sewn-in care label for fabric content. Our rule of thumb for blended fabric is to wash according to the highest percentage. i.e. if your sweater is 70% cashmere and 30% silk, wash with Wool & Cashmere and follow the appropriate washing recipe.

 

When to use what product:

  • For washing cottons, linens, everyday textiles, use the respective Whites Detergent or Darks Detergent.
  • Signature Detergent is for all-purpose laundering.
  • Wool & Cashmere Shampoo is specifically formulated for washing animal hair yarns to preserve the natural lanolin and oils.
  • Delicate Wash is formulated for washing silk and synthetic blends.
  • Fabric Softener is to be used on cotton/linens and general laundering - not to be used when washing woolens or delicates.
  • For whitening and general cleaning, The Laundress All-Purpose Bleach Alternative will safely whiten, brighten and disinfect your clothing. Perfect when pre-treating stubborn stains and dingy whites or just add to your washing cycle. Natural and color safe.
  • Always examine for stains before washing! Pre-treat accordingly with Stain Solution and Stain Brush or Wash & Stain Bar.

Know Your Equipment

  • Intense cleaning involves three elements: water temperature (hot), detergent amount (more) and agitation (movement in machine). Fabric, such as cotton, generally has a certain maximum shrinkage capacity so washing your favorite white t-shirt once in hot water will shrink the same amount as it would over multiple washings in warm.
  • Always reference what fabric you are washing to determine the proper water temperature to use. Cotton and linen are best washed with hot water, silk and synthetics are best at warm or tepid, and wools should always be washed with cold.
  • Washing cycles are just as important as water temperature. Too much agitation even with cold water can shrink a wool sweater. Always use the delicates or woolens cycle when machine washing "delicates or woolens."
  • For more specific instructions, visit our washing guide, Can I Be Washed?

Content.name: General Stain Removal
Content.description:
No matter what the stain, The Laundress will help you remove it!

 

The The Laundress Stain Solution is formulated specifically to target and break down stubborn stains such as red wine, sauce, chocolate, grass, coffee/tea, grease, blood, pit stains and more.

 
  • Apply The Laundress Stain Solution to the stain.
  • Work the Solution into the stained area with our Stain Brush.
  • Pour hot water from a height to be more effective and soak.*
  • If stain has faded, but isn't completely gone, repeat the process until satisfied.
  • Launder as normal.
    • *We recommended this process on durable fibers such as cotton, linen and some synthetic materials. *For stain removal on delicate fabrics such as silk and cashmere, use tepid water. Do not soak silk longer than 30 minutes at a time. *When treating stain from blood, always use cold water.

The Laundress Wash & Stain Bar is perfect for ring-around-the-collar, soil, oils, sunscreen and sunless tanner stains. The bar is the most convenient tool for spot-cleaning and getting to those hard to reach areas.

  • For spot-treating: Wet Wash & Stain Bar and stain, working the Bar directly into the stained area.
  • If stain has faded, but isn't completely gone, repeat the process until satisfied.
  • Launder as normal.
    • *The Bar is not as effective as our Stain Solution for removing wine, coffee, tea and fruit juice (tannins) stains.

The Laundress All-Purpose Bleach Alternative is excellent to treat overall dinginess for whites and colors.

  • Pre-soak in a washing bucket or add to your normal washing cycle with detergent in the machine.
  • If treating direct spots, work Stain Solution into the stained area with our Stain Brush and follow instructions above.

The Laundress Scented Vinegar is effective in removing stubborn, pesky odors on textiles from smoke, underarm odors, mildew and more.

  • Pre-soak with a cup in a washing bucket or add to your washing cycle in the machine.
  • Launder with a detergent as normal.
Enjoy your "new" stain free items!

Content.name: Tips & Tricks for Cleaning with Vinegar
Content.description:
Vinegar may be one of the most versatile (and under-appreciated!) products in your home. Here's just a few uses...

   

Remove odor on fabric - you know, that pesky odor retention in fabric that just doesn't come out in the wash?

 

Pre-treat/Soak

  • Soak with The Laundress Scented Vinegar before washing. (For cottons/synthetic materials soak for at least an hour, woolens/synthetics 30 min max.) Soak items in a basin with water - use hot water when applicable.

Launder

  • Run a load of laundry on the normal wash cycle with one cup vinegar. Follow with a regular wash cycle with detergent.
  • Apply directly on the underarm or odor area before washing
    • **do not soak vinegar on silk, acetate, and rayon

Non Toxic Kitchen Cleaning - De-odorize the air, refrigerator, microwave and more!

  Get rid of cooking smells by simmering a small pot of 1/2 cup vinegar and water. Keep a small bowl of vinegar on the counter to absorb odor.  

Refrigerator

  • Put 1 cup vinegar in a glass in the refrigerator for two days to remove odor - or keep refreshing if you have a constant problem.

Microwave

  • Use cup vinegar and 1 cup water bring to a boil and let sit.

Dishwasher

  • Add 1/2 cup vinegar to the rinse cycle or add 1 cups vinegar with dish detergent and run a full cycle to rinse spotty glassware.

Remove and inhibit bacteria, mold and yeast growth to acceptable levels

  • Cutting Boards - Apply vinegar directly on cutting boards at the end of the evening and do not rinse.
  • Countertops - Spray kitchen countertops and wipe down (this will also keep ants and bugs away).

Natural drain cleaner for tubs, sinks and taps - Clean, deodorize and unclog drains!

 

Unclogging Drains

  • Mix 1 cup baking soda (even better is with 1/4 cup The Laundress All-Purpose Bleach Alternative!) and 1 cup boiling vinegar. Pour down drain and let sit for 5 minutes then run hot water down the drain.
    • *This is also great in half proportion for the garbage disposal

Cleaning

  • Apply vinegar directly to the area with a cloth or sponge.
    • *We recommend mixing vinegar with The Laundress All-Purpose Bleach Alternative as a great way to scrub/clean tubs, tiles, toilets and stained porcelain. (Using The Laundress Scrub Brush, of course!)  

    Toilet

    • Deodorize with 1 cup vinegar, let sit for at least a half hour and then flush.

    Clean Blinds and Walls

    • Mix equal parts water and vinegar in a pail and use a sponge or The Laundress Lint Free Cleaning Cloths to wipe down walls and blinds.

    Clean Pergo "Wood" Floors

    • Pergo floors should be cleaned with vinegar vs. any other products floor cleaners, all-purpose cleaners, and wax as they leave a film. Use 1/4 cup vinegar with 1 gallon water to mop.

    Smelly Pet or Skunk Spray

    • Rinse dog with water. Mix 1 cup vinegar with 2 gallons of water and saturate the dog's coat with solution. Dry off without rinsing.

Content.name: Tips & Tricks for Conserving Energy
Content.description:
Energy prices are high and resources are ever dwindling. Luckily, there are things you can easily do to help conserve energy!

      A study by Cambridge University's Institute of Manufacturing found that 60% of the energy associated with a piece of clothing is spent in washing and drying it. Over its lifetime, a t-shirt can send up to 9 lbs. of carbon dioxide into the air!  

The following tips can save you over hundreds of dollars per year, preserve your clothing and the earth!

 

AVOID USING HOT WATER

Use warm or cold water for the wash cycle instead of hot (except for greasy stains) and only use cold for rinsing. 90% of the energy used in washing clothes is driven by the temperature of the water used. Reducing your hot water temperature setting from hot to warm could reduce a load's energy in half. Turn down the thermostat on your water heater. A setting of 120 F is adequate for most home needs. The temperature of the rinse water does not affect cleaning, so always set the washing machine on cold water rinse.  

WASH ACCORDING TO THE FABRIC TYPE & HOW DIRTY YOUR CLOTHES ARE

Do not over-wash clothes. Delicate clothes do not need a long wash like dirty clothes do. For heavily soiled garments, pre-treat stains with The Laundress Stain Solution or Wash & Stain Bar and then pre-soak. You'll avoid two washings and save energy!  

LOAD WASHER TO CAPACITY

Load the washing machine to capacity when possible. Washing one large load will take less energy than washing two loads on a low or medium setting.  

USE THE LAUNDRESS SPECIALTY DETERGENTS

The Laundress Detergents are ultra concentrated, so you use less but get more. Do not use too much detergent. In top-loading machines add 3 capfuls (1/4 cup, 2 oz, 60 ml) In HE and front-loading machines use 1.5 capfuls (1/8 cup, 1 oz, 30 ml) or suggested dispenser amount. Over-sudsing makes your machine work harder and uses more energy.  

MAINTAIN YOUR WASHER

Clean your washer monthly; machine build up, lime scale and rust in your washer can raise energy bills up to 25%. Add (1/2 cup, 4 oz, 120 ml) to your machine dispenser and run a long load with hot water.  

MAINTAIN YOUR DRYER

Your dryer drum collects lint and can affect the efficiency of your dryer. Use a cloth or sponge and dip in cleaning solution (One capful of The Laundress Stain Solution and 1 liter of water). Wipe inside of dryer to remove lint. Clean the dryer filter after each use. A clogged filter will restrict flow and reduce dryer performance. Check the outside dryer exhaust vent. Make sure it is clean and that the flapper on the outside hood opens and closes freely. Locate your dryer in a heated space. Putting it in a cold or damp basement or an unheated garage will make the dryer work harder and less efficiently.  

DON'T OVERDRY CLOTHING

Take clothes out while they are slightly damp to reduce the need for ironing - another big energy user. If your dryer has a setting for auto-dry, be sure to use it instead of the timer to avoid wasting energy.  

DRY SIMILAR FABRICS TOGETHER

Separate your clothes and dry similar types of clothes together. Lightweight synthetics dry much quicker than bath towels and natural fiber clothes. Dry full loads when possible, but be careful not to overfill the dryer. Drying small loads wastes energy - air should be able to circulate freely around the drying clothes. Do not add wet items to a load that is already partially dried. Try to dry two or more loads in a row - taking advantage of the heat still in the dryer from the first load.  

LINE DRY OUTSIDE

6% - 10% of residential energy use goes towards the electric dryer. If Americans, or even just New Englanders, would use the clothesline or wooden drying racks, the savings would be enough to close several power plants!  

Top 5 Reasons to Line Dry:

1. Save money (more than $100 a year off electric bill for most households). 2. Conserves energy and the environment. 3. Dryer fires account for about 15,600 structure fires, 15 deaths and 400 injuries annually. The yearly national fire loss for dryer fires in structures is estimated at $99 million. 4. Clothes last longer. Where do you think lint comes from? 5. Sunlight bleaches and disinfects. Indoor racks can humidify in dry winter weather.* *In the Pacific Northwest and other locations prone to indoor mold, you should be careful before hang drying your clothing basement.  

SKIP IRONING

Cut your electricity bill and save time. Promptly take your clothes out of the dryer so they don't wrinkle or even better, line dry your clothes. Use The Laundress Crease Release to soothe out wrinkles. Elimination of tumble drying (which uses around 60% of the use phase energy) and ironing, along with a lower wash temperature, will lead to around 50% reduction in global climate change impact of the product. Want to Learn More?
  • http://www.ifm.eng.cam.ac.uk/sustainability/projects/mass/UK_textiles.pdf
  • http://www.laundrylist.org/
  • http://www.cleaning101.com/
  • http://www.uppergreenside.org/2007/01/07/tips-for-saving-energy-and-money-doing-laundry/
  • http://www.doityourself.com/stry/laundrytips

Content.name: Tales from London - Wash & Stain Bar To The Rescue!
Content.description: Gwen recently visited London and came back with stories and pictures from her travels. Today she tells us about her Laundress emergency, the delicious salad that caused it, and the miracle solution she happened to be carrying with her. It was the first proper lunch I had had in 3 days in which I actually got to sit down to eat. I'd been running around so much, eating a sandwich while walking and shopping, grabbing a bite while racing around in a cab and so forth - I was quite looking forward to sampling some of the incredible cuisine London has to offer! I decided to treat myself to the salad specials at the Rose Bakery at the Dover Street Market. Anyone who still thinks the food in Britain is bad is GROSSLY mistaken. Anyhow, I enjoyed my salads immensely, except I had splattered some of that delicious salad dressing on my white t-shirt. I still had another Laundress meeting, appointment and a dinner for that day with no time to waste. Being the Laundress lady - I certainly couldn't tout a very noticeable stain around! Luckily I had a Wash & Stain Bar in my bag that I planned on giving to my next client, so off I went to the bathroom to operate. A few things to note here. As a rule, I can't stand stain removing during the day while wearing a garment - the wet blob just drives me crazy - but this was an emergency and had to be done. Secondly, there is nothing worse than using PAPER products in this procedure. But again, it had to be done, as it was my only resource in the bathroom. Here was my process : I wet the bar and rubbed it on the stain. I needed a little more water, so I blotted the area* *blot is the operative word here, do so very gingerly with water on the paper towel, you do not want to transfer paper pulp on your fabric and make the stain even worse with floating pulp. To finish, I stuffed some fresh paper between me and the shirt to aid in the drying process, and to lift the uncomfortably wet bit from my chest. Presto - Gonzo!   Next time, we'll hear about the appointment Gwen went to afterwards!

Content.name: New Media Roundup - August 2012
Content.description:
Just thought we would share with you today a few of the recent mentions we've had in and around the interweb! Being a professional Laundress can be a tough job - especially when there are so many questions to be answered. But a laundress has got to do what a laundress has got to do - and our Laundress ladies do it with pleasure. Lindsey was asked by the Houston Chronicle about the Do's & Dont's of laundering linens for a piece they wrote on the importance of investing in your home linens.
Racked had a different sort of question for Lindsey - this one not about laundry at all!
Go to Racked to see Lindsey's favorite shop in New York City.
And finally, a bit of a cautionary tale. Erica's Demonstration at Bloomingdale's
Content.description:
Our rockstar Sales Manager Erica Vendettuoli recently visited Bloomingdale's in Manhattan to give their Cashmere Shop Sales Associates a demonstration with the Laundress Wool & Cashmere Shampoo. Upon hearing about the visit, I was filled with questions - she was kind enough to answer a couple of them below.

What does that training entail exactly, and why now?
I generally visit our stores in New York quarterly. During a training I will cover a brief history of the company (why&how we were founded), educate the staff on our products in the store's inventory, and will instruct the staff on how to use it - sometimes I will even do a demo!

For this training with Bloomingdale's, I met with the sales associates in the cashmere department, as they will now be selling our Wool & Cashmere Shampoo. The images are of the demonstration I did - hand washing a cashmere scarf.

What's the purpose of these visits?
This is to help the associates with selling The Laundress products. I will always hand out samples of the product for the staff to try; after the sales people have the opportunity to try our products, it becomes much easier to for them to speak to clients about the Laundress.

Do you do trainings like this often?
I visit all New York stores quarterly- to meet new staff members, introduce new products, and sometimes I will even work on the floor directly with a store's clients. For stores not located in New York, I typically will set up a training conference call towards the same purposes.

What sort of reaction do you get from salespeople - do you ever encounter any surprise that cashmere is best NOT dry cleaned?
Most salespeople are very surprised when I tell them it's actually better to wash their silk and wool/cashmere items - of course, they all agree that they do not like dry cleaning!

Content.name: Friday Tip Day : Fur Care
Content.description:
While serious fur care is best left to the professionals (find your closest Authorized Fur Care Specialist HERE), maintaining your furs throughout the season will save you significantly in the long run. As always, we do not recommend dry cleaning - especially in the case of fur - as it will only ruin your investment.

Our personal - at-home & DIY - approach to cleaning fur would be to sprinkle with cornstarch or other powder (some professional cleaners use corncobs and walnut shells!), let sit 30 mins, and shake out well. The powder absorbs the dust and dirt that has attached to the hairs and, when shaken out, leaves the fur cleaner without drying out the pelt.

Maintenance is Key! We've had great results using the Laundress Crease Release to keep our furs conditioned and soft, and our Fabric Fresh keep them free from odor!

Check here for the Fur Information Council of America's (FICA) fur care tips. For those who want more information on DIY Cleaning, check out this set of instructions. Braver, and more industrious, souls should read this guide to glazing (we have not tried this, but if you decide to take the plunge, let us know how it worked!) When all else fails, recycling your fur into a new piece is a great way to breathe new life into your investment - Check out this Starter Kit from industry veteran and our go-to expert Tom Moriber from Furever Furs.

Hope this helps - and best of luck!

Content.description:
A little goes a long way...

We love porcelain, but it's no secret that it can get dirty. And as much as we love to clean, we can't always get the job done in the most efficient timeframe...Yikes!

Our inbox has been "trapping" questions about lint, pills and hair!

So, how does one know when to use - and how to choose - between the Sweater Comb and the Sweater Stone? Here it is, because neither care instructions - nor your woolens - should be fuzzy. Pilling is a direct result of wearing. When fibers become loose, they form little balls, which are commonly found on loosely woven woolens, knitted synthetics and blends. Please Note : The Sweater Stone is not for use on silk, linen, or double-knit fabrics.

Content.description:
Whoever said silk couldn't be laundered in a washing machine was seriously mistaken.

At the Laundresswe pride ourselves in being able to clean even the most delicate of fabrics, especially because those are the ones we love most! Today's laundry lesson revolves around these two 100% silk pieces by Ralph Lauren. Both came inwrinkled and worn. Both left clean and smelling fresh! As much as we wouldn't like to admit it, we sweat. The solution? Use our Wash & Stain Bar and StainSolution to pre-treat the underarms and straps. They are formulated to work well on delicatefabrics. We love 100% silk fabrics not only because they are beautiful, but also because we know exactly whatsteps to take to keep them beautiful. We always recommend putting items in Mesh Laundry Bagsto keep them from pulling or getting caught on one another. This is especially helpful for items withembellishments or buttons. You can also put the Delicate Wash directly into the drum of the machine when you are ready to begin laundering. The nice thing about silk is that it doesn't stretch when drying. So, you can hang up silk blouses and pants without worry that they will strech out or dry funny. But before you do, make sure to steam them. Steaming when damp helps to remove any wrinkles the washing machine leaves behind. For a more complete guide, Check out our Silks & Delicates Recipe Page, or for quick reference - read our handy guide!

Content.name: Did You Know? The Laundress Fabric Glossary is a Great Resource!
The Laundress on Washing with Borax
Content.description: There has been a lot of hulabaloo about the safety of Borax - and since it is an ingredient we use in some of our product formulations - we thought we'd put our two cents in. Here's What You Need To Know: First, it is important to understand that there is a difference between sodium borate and boric acid : they are both comprised of boron, and have similar properties (learn more about that here). Much of the debate on blogs out there seems to confuse the two as interchangeable, they are not. Second, the Laundress uses a refined form of natural sodium borate in selected formulations, in concert with other natural ingredients such as enzymes, oils, plant-based surfactants and oxygen bleach alternatives (Want to know what "oxygen bleach" really means? Click Here.) For the record - we do not use harmful chemicals such as Volatile Organic Compounds, phosphates, phthalates or petroleum based surfactants. But back to Borax. There are risks involved with everything, from table salt to borax to bleach, and we all do our best to minimize risk while maximizing utility. The Laundress products are specially formulated to be safe and nontoxic. The Borax Decahydrate found in our Wash & Stain Bar, the All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and our well loved detergents is actually less toxic than both bleach and table salt. So - Have No Fear and Happy Laundering! But you don't have to take our word for it - here's some resources with vibrant discussion on the subject : herban lifestyle | Borax: Safe or not? Crunchy Betty | Getting to the Bottom of Borax: Is it Safe or Not? US National Library of Medicine National Institutes of Health | A human health risk assessment of boron (boric acid and borax) in drinking water.

Content.name: The Laundress on the Dangers of Mothballs
Content.description:
They look like candy and keep bugs at bay, but what are the real dangers of using mothballs on your clothes and in your home?

Here at The Laundress, we are committed not only to a clean home, but a healthy one as well. Because of this, we strongly recommend against the use of mothballs as insect repellant. Besides the awful smell that has the propensity to seep into every possible surface, the active ingredients have been linked to a myriad of health problems including anemia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and blood in the urine. Prolonged exposure to the poison is even worse - naphthalene breaks down in the body, and can cause liver and kidney damage, cancer and even DNA disturbances.
Exposure to the chemical naphthalene - found in some moth balls, tobacco smoke, emissions from coal- and wood-burning stoves and even some house paints - can damage kids' DNA in ways that may raise cancer risk. In a recent study of 113 5-year-olds, researchers from the Columbia Center for Children's Environmental Health (CCCEH) found "chromosomal aberrations" that scramble genetic coding in 30 kids.
Both naphthalene and paradichlorobenzene (the active ingredients in mothballs) are toxic fumigants - which means they volatilize into the air. This is a process similar to evaporation, but rather than becoming a gas, they carry as a vapor the same poison as the solid. In order to be an effective repellant, it must be present in high concentrations; concentrations high enough to be effective as pest control are equally as harmful to anyone exposed to them. Because of this, the use of mothballs seriously impairs indoor air quality - as evidenced by the fact that even the odor can be detected at a few parts per billion in the air (a proverbial drop in the ocean). While we love the smell, we do not recommend using cedar wood blocks or chips to store your goods. If you are using cedar wood, avoid direct contact with the textiles as the wood can transfer oil to fabric which creates hard to remove stains. Additional Reading : EPA.gov | Naphthalene Fact Sheet EPA.gov Air Toxics Web Site | Naphthalene Connecticut Department of Health | Moth Balls Can Be Dangerous to Children eHow.com | Natural Moth Repellent in Closets Philly.com | The Danger in Mothballs

Content.name: Sportswear Solutions : Stain & Odor Removal for Performance Fabrics
Content.description:
Now that it's beginning to get warmer outside - finally! - we want to burst out of the laundry room and run in the sunshine.

So, what does this mean for The Laundress? More sportswear in our Laundry! We couldn't approach spring without knowing that The Laundress Sport Detergent and Sport Spray are on our side. High-end synthetic fabrics from our favorite brands like LuLu Lemon, Nike or Under Armour can't compete with the odor of sweat. As much as we hate to admit it, our sportswear does start to smell after a while. This doesn't mean you should avoid synthetic fabrics; they are comfortable, breathable and sweat-wicking -- not to mention very cute!

We have some great tips to help you tackle the smelly sportswear dilemma.

This works to both remove and prevent sweat stains that can build up over time. The Wash & Stain Bar is perfect for sweat stains around the neck, too. Our Scented Vinegar combines two things we love: our classic fragrance and odor removal properties! Use it as a presoak for your synthetic sportswear before washing. For the tank top and sports bra, we added about cup of scented vinegar to a cool water bath - let soak for up to an hour. Change dirty water as needed. The Laundress Sport Detergent works to remove bacteria, body oils and odor. It is specifically formulated for our favorite moisture wicking, breathable, insulated and water repellent fabrics! Pour the appropriate amount of detergent directly into the drum. You can run the washing machine on the normal cycle with cool water. High heat from the dryer reduces elasticity and sweat wicking properties. Embrace the drying rack! Most of these synthetic fabrics dry quickly anyway--it's part of their "sweat wicking" nature. The Sport Spray adds an extra layer of freshness to your clean laundry. It also works well as a post-workout freshener. Just a few quick sprays reduces odors when you are on-the-go!

Have you tried The Laundress Surface Cleaner yet?

In an effort to clear out precious under-the-sink real estate, we created The Laundress Surface Cleaner to be effective on all surfaces throughout your home - because, why use ten products when you only need one? From appliances, sinks, countertops, stovetops, walls, tile and woodwork to granite, stone, finished wood, marble and steel, this work-horse can handle it all. Scented in our Home Scent No247 - an invigorating blend of bergamot, thyme, lavender, musk and ylang ylang - it cleans and refreshes with a perfectly crisp clean home smell, any day of the year. Stainless Steel appliances and fixtures inevitably fall victim to fingerprint smudges, leaving behind an appearance that's visually unappealing and messy. Easily remove prints and streaks with this multi-surface product. Stone countertops run a high risk for absorbing stubborn stains. Immediately spray counters and tables to effectively remove all spills, drips and mess. Use The Laundress Lint-Free Cleaning Clothes to save trees and get an unbeatable shine at the same time! Children's highchairs gather sticky food messes; safely clean up every meal and snack time. All-natural and highly effective, no need to fear chemicals around your kids. Tile backdrops accumulate hard water stains and spots - to avoid build-up, wipe down regularly and keep tile dry. Antiques and wooden furniture collect dust and dirt easily - now you can remove all soils without harming the finish.

Content.name: Washing With The Laundress : Removing Paint Stains
Content.description:
A Laundress experiment : Paint Removal!

Gwen repainted the floors in her apartment, a big spring clean project. Despite doing most of it in some old sweats and stealthily maneuvering in the studio apartment trying to paint herself out the door, she ended up painting a little bit of herself too - as well as her J.Crew down vest - oh no! Being one of the original Laundress ladies, Gwen brought her vest into our laundry lab for some good old-fashioned experimentation to try to remove the paint. We had some paint thinner on hand...she decided to start with the paint thinner, and go from there! Gwen poured the paint thinner into a glass bowl and grabbed some Q-tips. Despite - or perhaps because of - her career as an expert Laundress, she still reads the care label for both the down vest and the paint thinner! The vest is polyester with a down interior. The paint thinner label conveniently says that it is "widely used as a dry cleaner and spot remover for fabrics," but may be harmful to some synthetic fabrics. While polyester is a synthetic, we know that it is basically indestructible. So, in the name of science and experimentation, Gwen went for it! (We imagine this process is safe for colors and most durable fabrics) Use the Q-tips on trace areas. Dip it in the Paint Thinner and apply. Gwen found that it had little effect on larger stained areas. Wet the bar and apply it to the stain for some agitation. Make sure to work the bar into the fabric really well. Dip the cleaning cloth into the spirits, and rub it on top of the soapy areas. Plain paint thinner proved to be much more successful for paint removal in conjunction with the Wash & Stain Bar. Use an old toothbrush to budge some larger paint globs. Gwen used her fingernail, as she did not have an old toothbrush and didn't want to contaminate the laundry room's Stain Brush. Once Gwen was satisfied with the paint removal, she tossed the vest (and the cleaning cloth!) in the washing machine. She poured the appropriate amount of Signature Detergent into the drum and ran a regular cycle with warm water.

Content.name: Washing Service : Mystery Stain on a Cocktail Dress
Content.description:
Our Washing Service receives challenges of all kinds, from heirloom antiques to the perfect LBD, each in need of a bit of extra special Laundress Love. We recently received just such an LBD, which came to us with stains of a mysterious nature left over after an evening's wedding festivities.

Fabric : Polyester with beaded embellishment Problem : Mystery stains down the front Process : A customer brought in her favorite cocktail dress that she had recently worn to a wedding. She was upset about an unknown substance that ended up staining the front of the garment. We assured her we would be able to tackle the stain, and she trustingly left it in our hands. Here is what we did... We then allowed the solutions to sit on the fabric for a few minutes, before filling a basin with tepid water. Due to the delicate nature of the garment's embellishments, our product of choice for laundering was our Delicate Wash. We gently agitated the water and allowed the dress to soak for 10-15 minutes. During this process, we made sure to leave the top half of the dress out of the water, so as to protect the beading under the bust. After the dress had been gently laundered, we proceeded with the garment's final cleanse. The original water was dumped out of the basin and fresh water was used to rinse. At this time, we submerged the entire garment into the water - a necessary step - so as to not cause a difference in color between the top and bottom half. The dress was rinsed thoroughly, ridding the garment of all soap. After the final rinse, we gently pressed on the garment to get out any excess water, careful not to squeeze or twist the fabric. The dress was hung to dry, and we were pleased to see such a successful result - the dress was free of all stains!

Content.name: Prepping For Fall Do's & Don'ts
Content.description:
Ahh, Fall.

The turning of the leaves, the smell of wood stoves, the back to school circus...and we can't forget the storing of your summer items! As we approach the end of summer, here are some of our tips for prepping for fall and storing your summer wardrobe and linens. Avoid mystery stains from appearing when you pull out your items next summer. Perfume, body oils and food from wear are often initially undetectable, but can appear over time and leave stains behind, as well as becoming a potential food source for moths while stored. The best way to avoid moths and critters from getting to your clothing is breathable storage - like our Storage Bags, Under Bed Storage Bag and Storage Cubes. Starch yellows over time and will provide unpleasant surprises if left to sit during seasonal storage. Indeed, most fabrics need circulating air or they will begin to degrade - that rules out airtight plastic storage bins and means removing all dry cleaning plastic before storing as well. Plastic also provides the perfect breeding grounds for moisture accumulation... another big enemy to your textiles!

Content.name: Things We Love : Thanksgiving Past & Present
Content.description:
*Homemade Green Bean Casserole recipe courtesy of brooke's kitchen / Food52.com [learn_more caption="Ingredients"]
  • 1.5 pounds French green beans, ends trimmed
  • Vegetable oil for frying
  • 1 cup shallots, thinly sliced
  • 3 tablespoons flour, divided
  • 8 ounces mushrooms (shitake and baby bella or mixed), sliced
  • 2 tablespoons butter
  • 2 garlic cloves, minced
  • 1/4 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg
  • 1/4 cup dry white wine
  • 1 cup vegetable broth (or chicken)
  • 1 cup half and half
[/learn_more] [learn_more caption="Cooking Instructions"]
  • Preheat oven to 375 degrees.
  • Wash and trim green beans. Blanch in boiling, well-salted water. Immediately transfer to ice water bath and set aside.
  • Heat 1 to 2 inches of vegetable oil in a deep, medium skillet.
  • Pat shallots dry, then toss with 1 tablespoon of flour. Season with salt and pepper.
  • Fry shallots in oil (in batches) until golden brown, then transfer to a plate to drain on a paper towel.
  • Melt butter over medium heat in a medium pan or cast iron skillet. Add mushrooms and saute until mushrooms are golden brown. Add garlic and nutmeg and cook for another minute or two. Add 2 tablespoons of flour and cook for 1 minute. Slowly add white wine, cook for a minute and stirring to break up any flour lumps. Slowly add vegetable broth and bring to a boil.
  • Boil the mixture for another 2 minutes, then turn the heat down to medium-low.
  • Add half & half and cook, stirring, until mixture begins to thicken. Take off heat.
  • Add green beans to mushroom mixture. Add 1/4 cup of the fried shallots. Mix to combine and season to taste with salt and pepper.
  • Transfer green bean casserole to a 9x9 baking dish or bake in cast iron skillet. Sprinkle remaining shallots on top or around edges of casserole.
  • Bake for 20 minutes until green beans are warmed and mixture is a little bubbly.
[/learn_more]

Content.name: Things We Love : Tokyo - Take 3
Content.description:
Gwen recently visited Tokyo to see our Laundress Japan team and stores - and she managed to fit in a whole lot of shopping along the way. This week, she's sharing some of her favorite things to do when visiting Tokyo. Here's what Gwen had to say about her trip : Now that the holidays are over, I can go back and share another year's adventures in Tokyo. As the number of Laundress enthusiasts in Japan continues to grow, we love visiting to see what is going on there. This year was extra exciting - with our first free-standing shop in the amazing Lumine shopping mall in the Shinjuku station. This trip I organized slightly different - I planned to have the weekend to go out on my own, so I could explore old and new (to me) stores. I have still yet to see a temple or site - I enjoyed seeing the imperial park on a Sunday morning drive by in a cab.... But such is the nature of business travel! Americans are becoming increasingly familiar with the eco-friendly "no-brand" Japanese lifestyle company MUJI. Built upon the core principles of simplicity and sustainability, MUJI offers everything from notebooks to bed sheets to (no joke!) a fully furnished house. Visiting MUJI in Japan is an experience for even the most ardent fan - the store provides just about anything you can imagine! (Photo borrowed from this great post about shopping in Tokyo.) Click Here to get the cozy cape Gwen bought in (almost!) every color. FoundMUJI is a concept store that, in 2011, re-opened in the iconic brand's original location. The shop's inventory is comprised of the products that inspire the company; they sell simple and traditional tools and home goods found around the world. From World's First Muji Store Reborn as "Found Muji Aoyama"
What is "Found MUJI?" Mujirushi Ryohin has always put emphasis on "exploration and discovery," rather than on making things. We look at life from this perspective. We have searched the world for durable, long-lasting everyday items. We slightly update them to fit with changes in customs, culture, and lifestyle; and then reproduce them at a fair price. Under the name "Found MUJI," we started a journey in 2003 to find good products, ones which would take us further than ever into the remote corners of the Earth.
Tsutaya T-Site is a world away from your average bookstore. Housed in an incredibly designed site, and boasting an unbelievable selection of music, movies, magazines, stationary - even a travel department where you can plan for international adventures - this multi-building complex even has a concierge service team to help you locate whatever it is you may be seeking. When you find you've spent the better part of your day thumbing through books, you can always head upstairs to the lounge to sip a cocktail while you continue browsing. Find out more about Tsutaya Daikanyama - the Tsutaya for grownups - here, here and here. Here's what Gwen has to say: There are 3 buildings- 1st building holds the pen room, travel room, cooking and food room, magazines with music upstairs. The 2nd building has magazines continued, art and design, with a caf lounge upstairs. The 3rd building houses literature, upstairs is children's and dvd. I had a lovely caf and regroup in the lounge - not to be confused with the downstairs Starbucks or convenience shop - and I spent forever in the magazine and art/design rooms. They have the largest selection of international magazines I have ever seen! After hanging out in the listening booth/display, I bought a few amazing CD's of jazz compilations from Japanese DJ's - this, of course, came with the best gift wrap...sadly, none of which is documented in my photos. Gwen says: As I am not a fan of Japanese food, I planned ahead to find some new places to try, looking to some trusted food resources for recommendations. I always love to visit Heidi's food blog - 101Cookbooks.com - and found her 2 Weeks in Japan post to be filled with exciting food options - including this vegetarian haven in the heart of Tokyo.   (Images borrowed from this delightful post about the cafe) What was once just a tiny neighborhood in the sprawling city of Tokyo has now become an international way of life. A stroll through Harajuku, however, never fails to surprise and delight. With some of the most over top fashions to be found world-wide, Gwen could hardly put her camera down! Anyone who knows Gwen well, knows about her deep and abiding love for good stationary. Trips to Japan are, thus, invariably peppered with visits to some of the country's best stationary stores - and Itoya certainly tops that list. Find out more about Itoya here and here. Soon I will be able to do an entire post of all my Rose bakery visits! There is nothing better than a visit to Rose Bakery after a long day of exploring. I had two this trip - at the Dover Street Market and in Isetan Shinjuko. The Pumpkin Chocolate Chip Cake slice is still on the top of my mind... Luckily I had no stain mishaps like in London - remember this? Check out Rose Bakery here, or read this review for more. Another place I found from 101CookBooks (Tokyo Travel) - I loved my visit to Junteuchi Soba Yumeji, and despite the language barrier the owners/couple were so happy to have me and thrilled I had come via Heidi's suggestion. Apparently there have been a few of us followers along the way... Don't worry - we aren't done with Tokyo yet! Visit us next week for more from Gwen's Japanese adventures - complete with a walking tour you can follow... you know, the next time you find yourself with time to kill in Tokyo.

Content.name: Gwen's Walking Tour of Tokyo
Content.description:
Traveling can be tough sometimes!

While in Tokyo, Gwen had a very full itinerary of store visits and shopping... And today we are taking the walking tour with her - with the help of some photos she took along the way! Always prepared, she started the fully packed day with a comfortable pair of shoes and some high energy snacks.     Roppongi is one of the livelier neighborhoods in Tokyo; long known for it's yakuza connections, it is also an area famed for its nightlife (no surprise there). In addition to a cacophony of bars, nightclubs and izakaya joints, Roppongi is also filled with a diverse array of shopping, museums and fine dining. (Check out this article for 101 Things to do in Roppongi) The Laundress has several retailers in the Roppongi district, and Gwen paid visits to some incredible stores while there. Living Motif is a lifestyle store chock full of incredible home and kitchen products with a motto of "lifestyles where design matters." Next up was Agito and EST Nation, which had the most adorable kids area where children could work on art projects while their parents shop.     From Roppongi, Gwen went north, passed the Imperial Palace, then east to visit the Marunouchi district, which holds the massive Tokyo Rail Station, as well as the Conran Shop, where she had to take home this "toothy" toothbrush holder. She also happened upon a delightful celebration of the traditional Japanese Aizu culture, which was located in what is now known as Fukushima.     Gwen's next stop was the business district of Yurakuchou, south of Marunouchi, and home to another EST Nation (for more shop visits), as well as one of Gwen's most anticipated stops of the day - the Monocle Cafe. Opened by Tyler Brule of Monocle Magazine, Monocle Cafe serves the favorite foods of its famous founder; Gwen was able to rest and revive during a much needed break.   Check out Tyler's Financial Times articles - Gwen's favorite - here.     It was a quick jaunt around the corner to arrive in one of the most famous luxury shopping areas in the world - Ginza. A trip to Barney's, a stop at John Smedley, and quick visits to Dover Street Market and the Uniqlo flagship rounded out Gwen's time in Ginza.   (Uniqlo image borrowed from TokyoFashion.com | Uniqlo Ginza Megastore Opens In Tokyo)     Omotesando, adjacent to Harajuku, is known as "Tokyo's Champs-Elysees" for its many architecturally significant flagship luxury brand stores, such as Louis Vuitton, Dior and Prada. Gwen's big stops here were a visit to Tomorrowland and the Entrex Square Store - to check in on our Laundress displays - and a trip to Daylesford Organic, where we celebrated The Laundress 5th Anniversary in Japan!     From Omotesando, it is only a couple blocks to Aoyama, a popular entertainment and shopping district among Tokyo's teens. The neighborhood is also home to one of Gwen and Lindsey's most favorite places, Spiral Market, a massive complex including a cafe, garden, exhibition space, record store and, of course, a truly excellent stationary store. Gwen also counldn't resist a stop in at the Intersect by Lexus compound for a moment of calm in the Lexus Bistro.     The last stops of the day are in the Shinjuku ward, where Gwen checked out the tartan explosion at Isetan (see what we did there?) - and our Laundress Fabric Fresh collab addition to the promotion. There was also a trip to the Takashamaya "real life" superstore, complete with a look at the kimono salon & children's school uniform areas, impeccably packaged cantaloupes and some very elegant kids toys. *Gwen Says : My kids list had these two to blame...I had a whole basket of Hello Kitty stickers until I saw these two (pictured above)..and I was embarrassed - so they all went back. Next on the itinerary was Tokyu Hands, something of a cross between Home Depot and Target; Gwen was especially delighted by the Science department's selection (see fish and frogs above), as well as the science-experiment style coffee maker. The last visit of the day was another highly anticipated one - The Laundress Store at Lumine2. We previously gave a mini tour of our shop in this post, check it out for pictures - and a map! If you've made it this far, you are a trooper! And...because Japan is all about the cute - we are going to close with two of the cutest things Gwen saw on her Walking Tour. You are very welcome.

Content.name: Things We Love : Gwen's Birthday
Content.description:
Ever the traveler, Gwen is heading back out - this time to spend her birthday in Paris!

This week, we bring you the francophile's dream Things We Love, with Gwen's list of the best places to go, things to see and delicacies to eat while in the City of Lights. I will be celebrating this year's birthday alone....but you don't have to feel too bad for me, as at least I will be in Paris. While I am headed to Frankfurt for work, I will be spending a few days in Paris after laundry shopping - and smelling - before a much anticipated weekend in Paris with my Valentine. The Grand Palais is a gloriously designed Beaux-Arts exhibition space and museum complex situated along the Champs-lyses and the Seine in the 8th arrondissement of Paris. Traditionally home to Chanel's runway shows, the Palais is also home to several annual exhibitions and museum spaces. Currently showing - better hurry, show ends February 16th - is an intensive and comprehensive exhibition of Cartier's pieces throughout history. Click Here to read more about the Cartier Exhibition. I was just recommended to see the Mugler Follies Dinner Show, perhaps I will treat myself to a night out on the town! Even though Princess Tam Tam recently started selling in the US - the Paris boutiques still have a much more fabulous collection of items! I am still kicking myself from leaving an Hermes bag behind way back when! This time around, I am hoping to find another gem for my wall like I did in Florence at the market. The Paris Flea is daunting to even the most seasoned of shoppers - check out this guide to the best spots for fabulous finds! And of course, I'll have to start the day with a birthday boulangerie - I'll be checking this list for the perfect croissant. Brasserie Balzar is one of the most famous of the typical Parisian cafes, where Camus and Sartre first decided to join the resistance, and where countless Parisians and tourists alike have enjoyed a classic french meal or cafe. Read reviews of Le Balzar here, here and here. (Rum Baba photo courtesy of Trip Advisor here.) Apparently, Lindsey and I are not the only french pharmacy junkies - check out Goop's post on Pharmacy Shopping. And of course, I will have to treat myself to something fabulous .... thankfully, I have this list of the best shops to guide me. I will report back with a new must see, do, and - of course - buy from Paris when I get back! au revoir! Xo, Gwen

Content.name: Recipe for Spring Cleaning
Content.description:
This is just about our most favorite time of year, spring cleaning and getting ready for the sunny days ahead! We've got a laundry list (and more) of home cleaning tips for the ultimate spring clean - more after the jump!

 
Recipe for Spring Cleaning
 
Author: The Laundress
Here's our laundry list (couldn't resist) of home cleaning tips for the ultimate spring clean.
Ingredients
  • Ironing Water
  • Fabric Fresh Classic
  • Signature Detergent
  • All-Purpose Bleach Alternative
  • Feather Duster
  • Glass & Mirror Cleaner
  • White Gauze Linen Kitchen Cloth
  • Scrub Brush
  • All-Purpose Cleaning Concentrate
  • Duster for Small Spaces
  • Wool & Cashmere Shampoo
  • All-Purpose Storage Bag
  • Surface Cleaner
  • Lint-Free Cleaning Clothes
  • Goat Hair Duster Wand
Instructions
  1. Kill mites and bacteria lingering on your mattress by flipping it regularly and steaming with the Jiffy Steamer.
  2. Add Ironing Water to the steamer or spritz with Fabric Fresh Classic to make your dreams extra sweet!
  3. Machine wash shower curtains and liners with Signature Detergent to keep them fresh and squeaky clean. Add a little All-Purpose Bleach Alternative to the mix to help remove soap buildup.
  4. Pick up loose dust and dirt sitting on light fixtures and chandeliers with the Feather Duster. For ornate fixtures, use the Glass & Mirror Cleaner and White Gauze Linen Kitchen Cloth to wipe down hard to reach areas.
  5. Give your freezer a deep clean. Lift left-over food spillage using the Scrub Brush with a mixture of All-Purpose Cleaning Concentrate, All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and hot water.
  6. Deodorize carpets and rugs with the All-Purpose Bleach Alternative. Simply sprinkle the Bleach Alternative beads onto the rug or carpet and vacuum clean.
  7. Include your computer and keyboard in the spring cleaning extravaganza. Lift dust or food crumbs from electronics by brushing with the Duster for Small Spaces.
  8. Before packing up your bubble coat or winter jacket, launder with the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo. Store in breathable fabric with a zipper closer for maximum protection - our All-Purpose Storage Bag does the job!
  9. Make windows glisten by wiping clean with the Glass & Mirror Cleaner and a Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth.
  10. Awaken those forgettable, hard to reach surfaces such as shelves and molding by wiping down with the Surface Cleaner and Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth, maintain with a quick swipe from the Goat Hair Duster Wand.
 
3.2.1310

Content.name: Things We Love : Spring Cleaning Tips
Content.description:
This is just about our most favorite time of year, spring cleaning and getting ready for the sunny days ahead! We've got a laundry list (and more) of home cleaning tips for the ultimate spring clean - more after the jump!     Kill mites and bacteria lingering on your mattress by flipping it regularly and steaming with the Jiffy Steamer.     Add Ironing Water to the steamer or spritz with Fabric Fresh Classic to make your dreams extra sweet! Find out more about Greening Your Home for a Fresh Year HERE.  

  Machine wash shower curtains and liners with Signature Detergent to keep them fresh and squeaky clean. Add a little All-Purpose Bleach Alternative to the mix to help remove soap buildup.     Pick up loose dust and dirt sitting on light fixtures and chandeliers with the Feather Duster. For ornate fixtures, use the Glass & Mirror Cleaner and White Gauze Linen Kitchen Cloth to wipe down hard to reach areas. Learn how to get your chandelier sparkling HERE.     Give your freezer a deep clean. Lift left-over food spillage using the Scrub Brush with a mixture of All-Purpose Cleaning Concentrate, All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and hot water. Get the skinny on how to clean your freezer HERE.     Deodorize carpets and rugs with the All-Purpose Bleach Alternative. Simply sprinkle the Bleach Alternative beads onto the rug or carpet and vacuum clean.     Include your computer and keyboard in the spring cleaning extravaganza. Lift dust or food crumbs from electronics by brushing with the Duster for Small Spaces. Find out how much We Love Dusting HERE.     Before packing up your bubble coat or winter jacket, launder with the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo (read more about that HERE). Store in breathable fabric with a zipper closer for maximum protection - our All-Purpose Storage Bag does the job!     Make windows glisten by wiping clean with the Glass & Mirror Cleaner and a Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth.     Awaken those forgettable, hard to reach surfaces such as shelves and molding by wiping down with the Surface Cleaner and Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth, maintain with a quick swipe from the Goat Hair Duster Wand.   Love the tips and wish you could save them? We're including a printable recipe for your convenience!  
Recipe for Spring Cleaning
 
Author: The Laundress
Here's our laundry list (couldn't resist) of home cleaning tips for the ultimate spring clean.
Ingredients
  • Ironing Water
  • Fabric Fresh Classic
  • Signature Detergent
  • All-Purpose Bleach Alternative
  • Feather Duster
  • Glass & Mirror Cleaner
  • White Gauze Linen Kitchen Cloth
  • Scrub Brush
  • All-Purpose Cleaning Concentrate
  • Duster for Small Spaces
  • Wool & Cashmere Shampoo
  • All-Purpose Storage Bag
  • Surface Cleaner
  • Lint-Free Cleaning Clothes
  • Goat Hair Duster Wand
Instructions
  1. Kill mites and bacteria lingering on your mattress by flipping it regularly and steaming with the Jiffy Steamer.
  2. Add Ironing Water to the steamer or spritz with Fabric Fresh Classic to make your dreams extra sweet!
  3. Machine wash shower curtains and liners with Signature Detergent to keep them fresh and squeaky clean. Add a little All-Purpose Bleach Alternative to the mix to help remove soap buildup.
  4. Pick up loose dust and dirt sitting on light fixtures and chandeliers with the Feather Duster. For ornate fixtures, use the Glass & Mirror Cleaner and White Gauze Linen Kitchen Cloth to wipe down hard to reach areas.
  5. Give your freezer a deep clean. Lift left-over food spillage using the Scrub Brush with a mixture of All-Purpose Cleaning Concentrate, All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and hot water.
  6. Deodorize carpets and rugs with the All-Purpose Bleach Alternative. Simply sprinkle the Bleach Alternative beads onto the rug or carpet and vacuum clean.
  7. Include your computer and keyboard in the spring cleaning extravaganza. Lift dust or food crumbs from electronics by brushing with the Duster for Small Spaces.
  8. Before packing up your bubble coat or winter jacket, launder with the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo. Store in breathable fabric with a zipper closer for maximum protection - our All-Purpose Storage Bag does the job!
  9. Make windows glisten by wiping clean with the Glass & Mirror Cleaner and a Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth.
  10. Awaken those forgettable, hard to reach surfaces such as shelves and molding by wiping down with the Surface Cleaner and Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth, maintain with a quick swipe from the Goat Hair Duster Wand.

Content.name: Cleaning A Bugaboo Stroller With Lindsey
Content.description:
We've Got Moms on the Mind!

  Discerning moms know that no stroller can compare to the Bugaboo. From the quality of the materials to the ingenious and versatile product design, the Bugaboo takes the stroller to the next level.   You may remember Lindsey's Bugaboo from our Cleaning A Stroller post oh so long ago...If not - you are in luck! We are going to show you how to clean a stroller - and not just any stroller at that! The all-terrain Chameleon3 adapts seamlessly into your life, whether you are running errands in the city, or running the trail with your little one - in fact, the only thing it seemingly doesn't do is wash itself! Check after the jump for our new and improved stroller cleaning tips...   [one_half]

STEP 1: PREP

SOFT AND SWEET | Bugaboo fabric components are easy off; remove cloth foot muffs, covers, and blankets at least once a month or if heavily soiled. Set the machine to a delicate cycle and launder in warm water with The Laundress Baby Detergent -- tough on stains but gentle for baby. Tumble dry on low (temp.) or hang dry.[/one_half] [one_half_last][/one_half_last]  

STEP 2: VACUUM

Time to remove all loose dust, dirt and crumbs from the stroller! Take a vacuum to the stroller to get everything out so you are ready to start with Step 3...    

STEP 3: STAIN REMOVAL

    Remove protein and oily/grease stains by pretreating and soaking fabrics. Lather with water and work The Laundress Wash & Stain Bar into stained area(s). Fill any sink or basin with hot water and let item(s) soak. Light spotting -- from drools and dribbles -- will be removed, while stubborn, set-in stains will loosen. Our All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and Stain Solution is a great duo for those tough stains once they have been pre-treated with the The Laundress Wash & Stain Bar.    

STEP 3: FINISH AND FRESHEN

To maintain that freshly laundered scent, use The Laundress Fabric Fresh Baby. For items that are not easily washed such as car seats, strollers, and stuffed animals spray to freshen; the natural antibacterial properties of "Baby" will remove odors.

Content.name: Prep Outdoor Furniture with The Laundress
Content.description:
The weather is warming up and outdoor entertaining is just around the corner...

With a little help from The Laundress, you'll have your patio furniture BBQ-ready in no time! Use these steps to rid removable cushion and pillow covers of mildew, mold and more....

Step 1

Remove loose mold with the Scrub Brush.  

Step 2

Apply Stain Solution and All-Purpose Bleach Alternative directly to the area, pouring hot water over top. Use the Scrub Brush to work this solution into the fabric.    

Step 3

Make a bath of hot water and Scented Vinegar and soak - the longer the better!  

Step 4

Machine wash in hot water with Signature Detergent - it's perfect for canvas fabrics.  

Step 5

For fabrics that are non-removable, simply follow Steps 1 & 2 and wipe clean with a Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth.  

Step 6

Do not dry until the mold is fully removed. We often treat items multiple times, so you may need to as well!   Read more at our FULL TUTORIAL on Removing Mildew and Mold.

Content.name: Cleaning & Storing Winter Items
Content.description:
It's a big job - and somebody's gotta do it...

We've been waiting patiently for temperatures to rise, and in the meantime, we're getting ready! Prepping your winter clothes for seasonal storage can seem like a overwhelming task, but if you follow a few simple guidelines, you'll be good to go. Always wash your items before putting them away for winter storage! Perfume, body products, body oil, food and dirt show up later and are much harder to get out. This also is true for starch - don't store items that are starched! All of the above are the feeding ground for bugs. Our Wool & Cashmere Shampoo will leave your clothes soft, fresh and ready to be packed away! Spritz with The Laundress Wool & Cashmere Spray and toss in a Lavender Pouch - both of which are safe, natural and effective bug preventers.
    • Do not hang knits, silks or synthetics.
    • Fur, leather and outerwear are best stored hung.
    • Delicate items and items prone to wrinkling are best when folded with acid free tissue.*
*Acid free tissue is essential for long term storing - not as important for season to season. Pack clothes and textiles in a breathable fabric, such as cotton or linen, and with a zipper closure. The Laundress All-Purpose Storage Bag has a versatile design that fits all your items. Never store in plastic or cardboard. Plastic bins, cardboard, and dry cleaner bags may look tidy, but are not suitable for good textile storage as they attract and encourage bugs and bug reproduction. Do not use drawer liners or contact paper as the adhesive can attract bugs as well. Items should be stored in a clean, cool, dark and dry area. Where is this? Only you really know, but not usually in an attic or basement - damp or humid areas such an attic or basement are optimal environments for moth breeding attacks, mold and mildew. Extreme temperatures will damage textiles and direct sunlight will fade and deteriorate fabrics as well.

Content.name: Make That Porcelain Sink Shine in 3 Simple Steps
Content.description:
We love porcelain, but it's no secret that it can get dirty.

Content.name: Handy How-To Video for Washing Delicates
Content.description:
We've got delicates on the mind with our #TakeOverTuesday gig over at Journelle's Instagram page. In honor of the occasion, we thought we would repost this handy how to video of Lindsey hand washing delicates... http://youtu.be/K_mOMaFcv3k  
WASHING DELICATES
 
Cuisine: Silks, Synthetics & Blends
Author: The Laundress
DELICATE ITEMS INCLUDE: Items containing any percentage of silk or silk-like synthetics Embellished items with hardware, embroidery, beading, or sequins Swimwear, activewear, and items made mostly of spandex or elastic Lacy or non-cotton underwear, bras, lingerie, and hosiery Anything made of lace or fine mesh Items labeled "Handwash Only" Most items labeled "Dry clean" Blends should be washed according to the highest fabric percentage, except for those containing silk or wool. Blends containing silk should be laundered according to the directions for delicates, while any blend containing wool or cashmere should be laundered according to the directions for wool.
Ingredients
  • Stain Solution
  • Wash & Stain Bar
  • Delicate Wash
  • Mesh Washing Bag
  • Delicate Spray
Instructions
  1. PRETREAT | Stain removal: Target areas such as underarms, necklines, and cuffs with the Stain Solution or Wash & Stain Bar.
  2. Odors: Add cup of white vinegar to a tepid water bath, and soak item for 30 minutes.
  3. Wash with like colors only.
  4. HANDWASHING | Handwashing is always the best and safest method for treating delicates.
  5. Prepare a "bath": Fill a wash basin or sink with tepid water and add 2 capfuls or a squirt of Delicate Wash.
  6. Submerge item: Gently agitate so your items will be evenly soaped and wet.
  7. Soak for up to 30 minutes--do not soak silk for longer.
  8. If there's color in the water: This is normal, the dye is simply releasing color. You will not notice any loss of color post wash.
  9. Rinse well: Run tepid water through items until rinse water is no longer soapy. Do not wring. Instead, press the water out of your item.
  10. MACHINE WASHING | Set machine to the delicate cycle. Make sure the water is cold.
  11. Place item, inside out, into a Mesh Washing Bag. Add the appropriate amount of Delicate Wash according to the label.
  12. Remove promptly from the washer to reduce creasing. Do not put in the dryer!
  13. DRY/FINISH | Hang to dry or lay item flat in its natural shape on a drying rack.
  14. Most delicate items require steaming. Do not iron!
  15. Freshen with Delicate Spray between wearing and washing.
 
3.2.1310

Content.name: Denim: To Wash or Not to Wash....
Content.description:
...?The Co-founders of The Laundress answer this burning question.

  The debate of to wash or not to wash denim has recently hit the airwaves with Chip Bergh, the CEO of Levi Strauss, stating that he hasn't washed his jeans in a year as part of their sustainability message. Our clients that take a "not to wash" stance are generally men as they want to keep color and avoid changing their 'perfect" worn in feel. While women are concerned about color and preserving their investment, laundering is imperative to redeem the fit/stretch of their jeans.   As we are a brand for everyone, we can advise for all washing concerns.   If you don't want to wash your denim we recommend a quick steam. According to Jiffy Steamer Co. 87 percent of bacteria is removed by steaming. Coupled with this and The Laundress Fabric Fresh - you are good to go. This is also a non-toxic freshening method with antibacterial properties. Spray before wearing, during or after.     If you want to wash your denim - that is ok and a preferred method by many. We created our Denim Wash, to preserve color and naturally soften so you can avoid the dryer (which is where most color loss and distress happens). From there they can either be air dried or put in the machine inside out for 20 minutes on a low setting. At all costs avoid the dry cleaner!     For white denim, we recommend adding our non-toxic, chlorine free and color safe All-Purpose Bleach Alternative with The Laundress Denim Wash and launder in hot water.     As an eco-friendly company, all our products are plant derived made with nontoxic, biodegradable, and allergen-free ingredients.   Free of petroleum, SLS, phosphate, phthalates, dyes, and animal by-products.   For more info, see our Denim Recipe Here.

Content.name: 5 Ways to Detox Your Home
Content.description: Detoxes call for flushing out the negative, the harmful, and the toxic to achieve a state of renewal, rejuvenation, and cleanliness. Think that this can only be achieved in your diet? Think again. With the Laundress' plant-derived, nontoxic, and allergen-free home cleaning collection, you can make your home environment feel just as cleansed. Five multi-purpose cleaning products are all it takes to transform your cleaning routine into a green one.     All-Purpose Bleach Alternative is 100% sodium percarbonate, chlorine-free, and oxygen based, making it family, pet, and food safe. Formulated without artificial dye, it's also color friendly!   Chlorine Bleach contains blue dye for colorant and hydrogen peroxide which agitates skin. Not to mention, its scent is strong and abrasive.       Glass & Mirror Cleaner contains streak-free cleaning enhancers derived from corn. Its sans-fragrance formula ensures residue-free results and high performance glucoside effortlessly removes dirt and grime.   Traditional Glass Cleaners have minimal to no cleaning enhancers and contain derivatives of formaldehyde as a wetting agent. Not only is this harmful to skin and eyes, it's also hazardous to the environment. Artificial dyes can also leave behind residue and stain fabrics.       All-Purpose Cleaning Concentrate is composed of plant-derived anionic and nonionic surfactants for optimal cleaning performance. The soil dispersant sodium gluconate boosts cleaning power and its No247 fragrance makes it pleasurable to the senses.   Toilet Bowl Cleaner contains hydrogen chloride which is known to be corrosive to eyes and skin.       Scented Vinegar is our corn derived, 100% natural vinegar. Known for its powerful cleaning properties that fight buildup, odor, and germs, vinegar's all-natural cleaning properties combined with the two-ply copper threads of the Copper Cloth will leave your oven flawless.   Traditional Oven Cleaner contains sodium hydroxide and ethanol both of which are immediate hazards upon contact and are deemed hazardous substances in numerous states. These harsh ingredients can damage aluminum and painted surfaces as well.     Home Spray freshens the room with minimal ingredients- deionized water, alcohol, essential oils, and fragrance. Completely free of phosphates and allergen causing materials, the Home Spray has antibacterial properties and is safe on fabrics!   Common Air Fresheners tend to contain sodium phosphate which causes skin irritation and negatively impacts surface water, not to mention their scents are often overbearing.

The Laundress begs to differ. Just follow our step by step instructions after each swim to get the most wears...

Wash & Stain Bar | Wash Basin | Sport Detergent

Pretreat stains with the Wash & Stain Bar, working it into the fabric, underwire, and straps.     Fix a bath of warm water and 1 capful of Sport Detergent and submerge your suit.           Create a mini whirlpool by agitating the water with your hands and leave to soak for 30 minutes.     Rinse the suit well under the faucet while gently squeezing out water. Content.name: How to Treat Mold & Mildew
Content.description:
There are no limitations to where mold and mildew can hunker down - if moisture and oxygen are present, mold and mildew can claim their stake. From leaky pipes to precipitation from the shower, the slightest bit of moisture can invite this pesky pair to contaminate your clothing, upholstery, and home. The icky issue can be contained and treated if addressed in a timely manner, so study our tips on removal and prevention to be 100% prepared if mold & mildew unexpectedly show up at your door...or on your favorite cotton shirt.  

REMOVAL

  When treating mold & mildew, time is of the essence! When you notice spots and stains, grab these tools ASAP: Stain Solution, All-Purpose Bleach Alternative, Scrub Brush, Scented Vinegar   1. Brush off loose mold. 2. Apply Stain Solution and All-Purpose Bleach Alternative to the affected area and work in with either the Scrub Brush or Stain Brush. The Scrub Brush should be used on durable fabrics, while the Stain Brush is appropriate for delicate pieces. 3. Soak in a bath of water and Scented Vinegar - the longer the better! 4. Repeat until satisfied - it may take a few tries!   Once you see the mold/mildew stain lifting, machine wash the item as normal. If the item is made of cotton, linen or a durable synthetic, wash in hot water.   Drying is the final step - make sure not to do so until all traces of mold are gone.  

PREVENTION

  Reduce indoor humidity - vents and de-humidifiers are key Be sure to use the exhaust fan when cooking When faced with a leak or water problem, fix immediately Always remove mold from hard surfaces with detergent and dry completely   For more information on mold, please visit www.epa.gov.

Content.name: Front Loader vs. Top Loader
Content.description:
The Laundress breaks down the difference between machines...

When it comes to laundering, using the correct detergent for fabric type is essential to maintaining your wardrobe - and you're obviously a Laundress fan so you've chosen the right one! The actual washing machine itself is just as important as the detergent you put inside of it, however. That's why understanding the differences between top loading and front loading washing machines is crucial in selecting a machine that meets the needs of you, your family, and your laundering routine.    

Capacity

When purchasing a top loading machine, one has the option of choosing a machine with an agitator or one sans agitator. Older machines with agitators typically hold less clothing making bulky items like down comforters more difficult to wash, however they are very effective at heavy duty cleaning and stain removal.

Cost

Top loaders are generally less expensive than their front loading counterparts.

Functionality

Top loaders are convenient in that, if you discover that missing sock at the bottom of your hamper and want to throw it into the machine with the rest of your load, you can! You can also lengthen soaking sessions.

Space

Because these machines are not able to be stacked on top of or beneath a dryer, they require greater floor space. While this may seem inconvenient, the top of the washer and dryer can serve as a nice work space for pretreating and folding laundry if placed side by side.

Gwen's Recommendation :

I prefer machines that allow the user to dictate the amount of water used rather than having water levels predetermined. Older machines allow you to control water levels via the load size dial, and now newer machines with computerized systems let you override the sensor system. Not only does this ensure the most effective clean, but it's also the most eco-conscious measure! This will help limit the number of instances where you have to wash and rewash a piece because it wasn't properly cleaned the first time around.    

Capacity

Front loading machines are generally able to hold more items and handle larger loads. Don't be deceived - while the door opening is smaller, the interior is large. What we love about newer, fancy front loaders is their gentle wash cycles which make them more appropriate for washing delicates.

Cost

While the machine itself does tend to have a higher price point, they use less water and electricity saving more money in the long run.

Functionality

Front loaders are not as convenient functionality-wise as clothing cannot be added during the wash cycle and they cannot be paused for longer soaking. The machine itself is more difficult to clean and earlier models are prone to producing an unpleasant odor around the door seal over time. *Tip: When not in use, leave the door open to avoid musty smells!

Space

Front loaders are able to be stacked and require less floor space - just make sure you have a roomy workspace close by!

Lindsey's Recommendation :

Drum size and gentle washing are priorities of mine so I prefer an LG front loader as its drum is notably larger than a Miele or Bosch. Their new steam and handwash functions as well as their ability to agitate without an actual agitator are all pluses for me. I wash pretty much everything on the delicate cycle!     [one_half]Deeming one brand "the best" is an impossible feat - it's completely up to your lifestyle, needs, space, and budget. If quality is priority, seek out European names that manufacture their goods in Europe. These machines tend to be constructed with heavier metals, rubber, and tubing. North American and Asian brands are commonly manufactured in Mexico and composed of less durable metals and plastics. Choosing a quality washing machine is similar to choosing a car - you can tell higher quality by the solidity of the machine. It is always best to purchase what is right for your lifestyle & laundering needs, however. If it were up to us - we would have 2 sets![/one_half][one_half_last] [/one_half_last]
