Content.name: How to Remove the Dreaded Pit Stain
Content.description:
The Ultimate Solution

  If there's one laundering challenge that we love to conquer more than the others, it's the dreaded "Pit Stain." Creating a cure for this unsightly stain was actually one of our main missions upon the start of The Laundress. A result of natural body oils, deodorant, and fabric absorption, everyone is prone to the yellowing of our favorite tees - with the summer heat, no one is exempt!   When it comes to the best removal method, pretreating is a must. Follow our "Pit Stain" recipe to help salvage your tops and restore them to new...     1. Stain Solution | 2. Stain Brush | 3. All-Purpose Bleach Alternative  

PRETREAT

  1. Apply Stain Solution & All-Purpose Bleach Alternative directly to the underarm areas.
  2. Pour hot water onto the mixture to dissolve and activate the All-Purpose Bleach Alternative beads.
  3. Work the solution into the fabric with the Stain Brush .
  4. Presoak the top in a bath of hot water and All-Purpose Bleach Alternative for at least 1 hour.
      *If the stain isn't fully removed at the soak's completion, don't fret! It often takes 2 to 3 tries before complete removal.
  5. Once satisfied, finish by laundering as normal with either the Signature Detergent or Whites Detergent

PLEASE NOTE

  This process is recommended for treating durable fibers such as cotton, linen, and some synthetic materials. The All-Purpose Bleach Alternative should not be used on silks, woolens, or leathers. For more information on caring for delicate items, click here!

Content.name: How To Clean Your Coffee Maker
Content.description:
With The Laundress team having a constant craving for coffee, our beloved machines get tired (and stained) from excessive use! That's when we queue a few handy products from our Home Cleaning Collection to remove coffee grinds, buildup, espresso stains, and more.

Recommended Products

 

1. Copper Cloth | 2. Scented Vinegar | 3. Dish Detergent | 4. All-Purpose Bleach Alternative  

Optional Products

Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth | Dish Brush
 

Start Cleaning!

Step 1 :

Disassemble the coffee maker, removing the rubber seal and strainer from the base of the top half.  

Step 2 :

Create a paste of All-Purpose Bleach Alternative & Scented Vinegar.  

Step 3 :

Using the Copper Cloth, apply the paste to the strainer, rubber seal, and top & bottom halves of the coffee maker. Give it a good scrub while you're at it.  

Step 4 :

Let the mixture sit on the parts - enjoy a cold brewed coffee while you wait! (If you don't already have some made, you can always try this method.)  

Step 5 :

Handwash the pieces with the Dish Detergent, rinse well, and let air dry.    

Et voila - all clean!

 

Don't Slack!

The more often the maker is cleaned the better the espresso will taste. Rinse well and flush the vinegar completely, if not your espresso may taste of vinegar or even worse....soap!

For Routine Cleaning...

This cleaning method is best for highly soiled machines. For routine cleaning, run Scented Vinegar through a long, full brew cycle. If it is a stovetop brewer, soak in vinegar and hot water overnight. Hand wash with Dish Detergent and the Dish Brush; rinse well and wipe dry. You should always wash a new coffee machine - or any kitchen appliance - before using for the first time. It's been packaged, transported, and handled by quite a few people, so a good clean is needed!

Content.name: Product Spotlight | Dish Detergent

For Washing by Dishwasher

Content.name: Introducing...The Launch of The Official Laundress Weibo
Content.description: Weibo is a leading social media platform for people to create, distribute, and discover Chinese-language content. Weibo represents a new online experience in China by combining the means of real-time public self-expression with a powerful platform for social interaction, as well as content aggregation and distribution. Content.name: Banish Odor with Scented Vinegar
Content.description:
A day-long brunch date with your friends or a late night out doesn't have to equate to extended hours in the laundry room. While your clothing may not exactly smell of the delicious fragrance you applied at the beginning of the day, removing any unpleasant odors like the smell of smoke or body odor can be hassle free if treated with Scented Vinegar. While known to have an off-putting scent itself, our No. 247 fragrance paired with this natural cleaning agent ensures you will experience all of its benefits and none of the smell.  

When Pretreating

Presoak items in a bath of water and Scented Vinegar: For cottons/durable synthetics, soak in hot water and vinegar for at least 1 hour. For woolens/silks, soak in cold water and vinegar for a maximum of 30 minutes. Follow by laundering as normal with one of our detergents, such as the No.10 Laundry Detergent, for that fine fragrance finish.  

When Machine Washing

Run a load of laundry on the normal cycle with 1 cup of Scented Vinegar and proceed with a second machine wash using only detergent. For particularly smelly circumstances, apply Scented Vinegar directly to the odorous area before the initial wash.  

When Out & About

If you catch wind of a questionable scent while out & about, don't fret! Simply spray one of our fabric sprays to deodorize and sanitize your garments as you're wearing them. What's best is that they're safe for all fabrics AND fit oh-so-well in your purse.

Content.name: The Ultimate "How To" for Cleaning the Toilet
Content.description:
We know that cleaning your toilet isn't the most glamorous of chores, and lucky for us it needs to be done fairly often! From hard water leaving behind mineral deposits to soft water prompting brown mold, deep cleans are needed to ensure you have a posh looking potty for both your guests and your family. While the fumes of traditional toilet bowl cleaners (chlorine bleach and ammonia) leave your head in a whirl, our scent-free All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and No. 247 Scented Vinegar allow you to breathe easy and require minimal effort - cheers for no scrubbing!   Sprinkle 1 capful of All-Purpose Bleach Alternative into the bowl.

Next, squirt Scented Vinegar or distilled white vinegar into the bowl with the Bleach Alternative.

Allow this powerful, yet natural mixture to soak. The Bleach Alternative will disinfect while the acidic Scented Vinegar will break down any mineral stains.

Flush the mixture - swirling the mess out of sight!

  If you're traveling away from home or have a toilet that's not often used, leave All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and Scented Vinegar to soak in the bowl!
  Looking for more toilet cleaning insight? See step-by-step pictures HERE.

Content.name: Machine Wash Your Silks!
Content.description:
Washing silk pieces can be intimidating, but did you know that they can actually be machine washed? In this Daily Candy video, Lindsey shows how to properly execute the task of laundering silk with Laundress essentials so that your go-to scarf for fall or elegant slip is fit for wearing.    

What to Note

It's normal for the dye in silk to bleed, especially with "garment dyed" pieces, so garments consisting of 2+ colors should be tested for bleeding prior to washing. ALWAYS machine wash silk on the delicate cycle in cold water. Insert pieces into a Mesh Bag to prevent snagging or tangling. Wash with like colors only. NEVER put silk in the dryer - it should always be hang dried/air dried. Steam while damp to reduce creasing.

Content.name: Gwen & Lindsey's Most Treasured Pieces
Content.description:
We all have those special pieces in our closets that stand apart from the rest. That certain item that is near and dear to our hearts and with which we could never bear to part! From an article of clothing that we splurged on to quilt passed down through the family, we will simply always love these timeless pieces.   Wondering what Gwen & Lindsey's most treasured items are? The Laundress ladies share with us their favorites!
 

Lindsey's Most Cherished Piece is...

  Any heirloom from my paternal Grandmother. She had such an amazing collection of antique quilts! This one is a family favorite that we use in the city for cold winter nights. It is perfectly worn in and provides just the right amount of warmth. It reminds me of my grandparents, more specifically visiting them at their farmhouse as a child. This one sat at the foot of my Grandmother's bed.   I recently had a few of the patches re-sewn at Newfane Country Store in Vermont and they did such an incredible job! Of course, I'll be washing my beloved quilt with No.10 Laundry Detergent this fall.
 

Gwen's Favorite Item in Her Closet is...

  My pashima scarf. My first job after college was working for Ralph Lauren in Manhattan as a part of the women's scarves and prints team. It was September 1998, just as we were showing the newly discovered material pashima from Nepal. We were the first to show them and had the most beautiful color palette as they were for the spring runway collection. I went down to TriBeCa to visit our sourcing team and I bought this stunning pink one. I think it was $300 and I totally did not have extra money to be spending on a scarf!   Needless to say, I have been wearing it (and washing it) ever since - and it just so happens to be in my suitcase today during my travel to Greece and the South of France!

Content.name: Repairing & Cleaning Washing Machines
Content.description:
Gwen dishes her personal washing machine experiences and why she thinks newer isn't necessarily better...

  My new summer home is perfectly suited for a Laundress - it has two sets of washing machines and a slop sink conveniently perched for handwashing. Just as I thought my laundering wishes had been fulfilled, the newer washer/dryer (a stack unit) managed to run without getting anything wet! A few hundred dollars later for a new motor and to my unpleasant surprise, it still didn't work! I settled for keeping these non-functioning machines as decorative pieces in my hallway. After all, who doesn't appreciate these beautiful machines!   This left me with my trusty old school washer - a Whirlpool - which still keeps churning like a superstar! Because the lid was pretty rusted, I ordered another online and replaced it myself. It's safe to say that I picked up some new handy skills that day! To get my Whirlpool running at its best, I drowned the dispensers with Scented Vinegar and sprinkled All-Purpose Bleach Alternative into the bleach dispenser running a lengthy, empty load with hot water.   A little wiping and crevice cleaning with the Surface Cleaner and a Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth and the machine looked brand new! With little effort, I now have a functioning, clean machine!  
 

Machine Maintenance

  Keep your washing machine at the top of its game by routinely cleaning with hot water and a solution of All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and Scented Vinegar.   For dryers, make sure to clear the drum as it collects lint which can affect its efficiency and leave fuzz behind on clean clothes. Wipe down the inside with a cloth and 1 capful of Stain Solution and water to remove lingering lint and hair.   For more machine cleaning instructions, click here!

Content.name: Product Spotlight | The Stain Brush
Content.description:

Wet both the Stain Brush and soiled area, apply Stain Solution, and brush.  

For heavy stains:

When dealing with durable fabrics, mix Stain Solution & All-Purpose Bleach Alternative to create paste and follow by working in the solution with the Stain Brush.  
    Wash the Stain Brush with hot water by hand.   For start to finish stain removal tips, check out our Stain Removal Recipe!

Content.name: How To Tackle Grass Stains
Content.description:
With lifeguard whistles replaced by the sound of school bells, summer vacation has officially concluded and the school year is in full swing. While your kids may not be thrilled for this change in season, no one can deny the excitement for fall sports - JV, varsity, college, and professional! From soccer and football to cross country and field hockey, pesky grass stains on jerseys and uniforms are inevitable. Just as these stains are the products of a little good, clean fun, they can be lifted with the application of some good cleaning agents like our Stain Solution. Enzyme-based to fight stains right at their source, it is the ultimate remedy for tough, protein stains like grass.  

Before You Wash

  • Apply Stain Solution directly to any grass or soil marks.
  • Work the Stain Solution into the fabric - you can use our Stain Brush, an old tooth brush, or your finger!
  • Pour hot water onto the area to more deeply work in the solution.
  • Soak in a bath of warm water and All-Purpose Bleach Alternative for at least 30 minutes.
  • If the stain has faded but isn't completely removed, repeat the process!
 

Launder as Normal

Washing items with grass stains in hot water makes for the most effective removal. For sports jerseys and uniforms that go through much wear and tear, wash with Sport Detergent. This will not only conquer grass stains, but will flush perspiration and body odor from performance fabrics like spandex. *Please note that the above methods are only recommended for cotton, linen, and durable synthetics. They should not be used on items containing silk, wool, or leather. For additional details on caring for active wear, check out our Product Spotlight on the Sport Detergent & Sport Spray!

Content.name: Cleaning Magic Marker Messes...
Content.description:
A fresh pack of Magic Markers for the new school year always means that new, vibrant stains will suddenly be appearing everywhere - from clothing to couches and countertops, no surface is safe! Having a little student of her own, Lindsey can attest to this colorful mess and BOTH mother and daughter are pros at removal. See what supplies you'll need for the first day of Magic Marker Removal 101 and how to pass the test. Your teachers? Why Chloe and Lindsey, of course!
 

FOR UPHOLSTERY

    1. Apply a squirt of Stain Solution directly to the stain. 2. Lather the Wash & Stain Bar with tepid water and work both the Bar and Stain Solution into the fabric. 3. Blot the area being treated with a damp cloth - such as the Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth - until all suds are clear. 4. Absorb excess moisture with a clean, dry cleaning cloth. 5. Air dry.  
 

FOR COUNTERTOPS & HARD SURFACES

    1. Spray Surface Cleaner onto the marker mess. 2. "Rinse" the surface with a damp, clean cloth like the Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth . 3. Wipe dry with a new, dry Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth - this will prevent water marks!  
 

FOR CLOTHING

Cotton, Linen & Durable Synthetics

    1. Apply Stain Solution directly to the stain. 2. Sprinkle All-Purpose Bleach Alternative onto the Stain Solution to create a powerful cleaning paste. 3. Pour hot water onto the solution and gently work this solution into the fabric with a Stain Brush . 4. Launder as normal in hot water with Signature Detergent . 5. Dry only when the stain is fully removed - drying prematurely will set in the stain!    
For pictures of the littlest Laundress removing marker all by herself, view our Marker Stain Cleanup with Chloe & Lindsey.

Content.name: How to Wash Wool & Cashmere
Content.description:
Wool & cashmere aren't just wonderful to wear - they're washable too! While often mislabeled (as dry-clean only), both fibers actually wash beautifully and are easy to maintain. Not only is caring for woolens from the comfort of your home more convenient and less expensive than dry cleaning, it helps to preserve fibers making your sweaters last longer!
 
 

STAINS: Treat stains with the Stain Solution or Wash & Stain Bar, and pretreat susceptible areas such as underarms, necklines, and cuffs.

ODORS: Presoak the item for 30 minutes in tepid water mixed with 1/4 cup Scented Vinegar - or white vinegar.

PREPARE TO HAND/MACHINE WASH: Wash with same/like colors only. Always turn item inside out.

 
 
 
[one_half] PREPARE A "BATH": Fill a wash basin or sink with cool water and add 2 capfuls, or a squirt, of Wool & Cashmere Shampoo. SUBMERGE ITEM: Gently agitate so your items will be evenly soaped and wet. Soak up to 30 minutes. [/one_half] [one_half_last] RINSE WELL: Run cool water through items until rinse water is no longer soapy. Do not wring. Instead, press the water out of your item. IF THERE IS COLOR IN THE WATER: This is normal; the yarn dye is simply releasing color. You will not notice any loss of color post wash. [/one_half_last]
 
  PREPARE TO WASH: Place item in a Mesh Washing Bag, inside out.   WASH: Select the Woolens/Delicate cycle. Make sure the water temperature is cold and the spin is on low. Add the appropriate amount of Wool & Cashmere Shampoo according to the machine and load size.
 
      [one_half] LAY FLAT TO DRY: Lay flat in its natural shape on a drying rack or clean towel. When drying, avoid direct sunlight and heat sources such as the radiator. Never hang wool. EXPEDITE DRYING: Lay flat on a towel. With the item in its original shape, roll up the item in the towel (like a sleeping bag) to remove the excess water. [/one_half][one_half_last] STEAMING IS RECOMMENDED: Do not iron wool, ironing will crush/flatten the natural pile of the yarns! FRESHEN: Keep items fresh between wearing and washing with the Wool & Cashmere Spray. [/one_half_last]
 
DE-PILL: Glide the Sweater Comb in one direction across pilled areas. The comb is ideal for fine gauge yarns. For heavier gauge items, glide the Sweater Stone over pilled areas. Always work tools in one direction. LINT: Remove lint, fuzz, and hair with the Cashmere Brush. Brushing between wears will release natural oils that rejuvenate yarns.     FOLD: Always store knits folded to prevent stretching or distorting. PEST PREVENTION: Prevent bug and moth infestation by storing in a breathable cotton/canvas bag with a zip closure. STORE CLEAN: Always store items clean to avoid inadvertently providing a "food source" for bugs.    
  • Handwashing is always the best and safest method for washing woolens.
  • Remove promptly from the washer to reduce creasing. Do not put in the dryer!

Content.name: How To Clean Backpacks & Lunchboxes
Content.description: Students should be stepping into the classroom with their best foot forward and jumping onto the school bus at the day's end with equations, literature, and science experiments buzzing through their heads! With a full day of excitement 5 days a week (wink, wink!), a spill, stain, or spot is bound to appear on school supplies that endure the most wear and tear: backpacks and lunchboxes. While the items held inside may be perishable, these two essentials should last more than one school year. With these easy cleaning tips, you can keep backpacks and lunchboxes year after year while making sure your child is sporting gear that looks like new!     Cotton, polyester, and durable fabrics   1. Clear out all school supplies. That means folders, papers, and writing utensils - not a pencil left behind! 2. Pretreat any stains. Treat marks on the interior and/or exterior of the fabric with Stain Solution, working it into the fabric with a Stain Brush. Marker and ink are common culprits! 3. Insert into a Mesh Bag. This will protect zippers and straps from tangling or snagging during the wash cycle. 4. Machine wash in hot water. Wash with Signature Detergent on the normal cycle, selecting hot water to achieve the deepest clean. 5. Hang to dry. Promptly remove the backpack from the washing machine and hang to dry. Make sure to leave all compartments unzipped for ventilation.     Hard, plastic shell   For food & drink spills Spray the interior and/or exterior of the lunchbox with Surface Cleaner and wipe clean with a Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth. A completely easy and hassle- free process! *Fun Fact: Made of natural, nontoxic ingredients, the Surface Cleaner is safe to use around kids and food and can clean all surfaces. For leftover lunch smells Wet a cleaning cloth (our Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth is ideal) with Scented Vinegar and wipe down both the interior and exterior of the lunchbox. Follow by "rinsing," using a new cleaning cloth damp with water to wipe surfaces clean. *Fun Fact: Vinegar is known for its powerful properties that fight stains, buildup, odors, and germs.

Content.name: Product Spotlight | Sweater Comb & Sweater Stone
Content.description:
Fall is officially here! Cue the merino turtlenecks, cashmere scarves and gloves, woolen throws, and all things made of fabrics that keep us oh-so warm and cuddly when bearing the brisk temperature. As these pieces offer us much needed relief from the elements, we can't help but wear them again and again...and again! Now, cue the pills. Pills occur from wearing (not a result of washing)! When fibers loosen, they form little balls, which tend to appear on loosely woven woolens, knitted synthetics, and blends. Luckily, we have not one, but TWO de-pilling tools that will maintain your pieces' appearances while protecting the fabrics' integrity. So which tool should you be using to satisfy all of your de-pilling needs: the Sweater Stone, the Sweater Comb, or both? *Ideal for delicate knits & fine gauge woolens   To be used on:
  • Thin, lightweight sweaters
  • Delicate scarves
  • Wool gloves
  • Pant legs
  • Cashmere robes
 

*Ideal for heavier woolens, thick gauge yarns & upholstery

[one_half][/one_half] To be used on: [one_half_last]
  • Thick, woolen sweaters
  • Suits
  • Outerwear
  • Blankets
  • Knit furniture & pillows
[/one_half_last]  
    For both the Sweater Comb AND Sweater Stone:
  • Lay the piece being treated on a flat surface.
  • Brush gently in one direction, using short strokes.
  • For best results, de-pill items prior to laundering.
    For lint and hair removal between wearing and washing, the Cashmere Brush is our go-to. Ideal for fine yarns, the Cashmere Brush works to rid lingering fuzzies and hair while rejuvenating the fibers' natural oils.

Content.name: How To Freshen Clothing Post-Storage
Content.description:
Re-introducing seasonally stored fall and winter clothing into your wardrobe and phasing out shorts and tank tops should be an effortless transition. You know how to store out-of-season garments like a pro, and getting your cozy, yet stylish woolens and cashmere ready for wearing is as easy as Steam, Spray, Brush (and Launder of course)! Steam out wrinkles and fluff yarns using a steamer. Add a capful of Ironing Water to the mix to ignite the beautifully fresh Classic scent. Steaming also kills germs and bacteria. Don't have a steamer handy? Use an iron set to the "steam" setting, hovering over the item - do not make contact. Pressing an iron on wool will crush or flatten their sensitive fibers.  

Banish musty odors and freshen garments by spritzing one of our fabric sprays - Wool & Cashmere Spray and Fabric Fresh Classic are perfect for this task!

  Rejuvenate the natural oils of fibers by brushing wool and cashmere pieces with the Cashmere Brush.     Mildly Yellowed Add 1?4 cup of Scented Vinegar to a wash load or handwashing basin in conjunction with the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo and wash as normal.   Moderately to Extremely Yellowed Presoak the garment in a bath of cool water mixed with 1?4 cup of Scented Vinegar and leave to sit for no longer than 30 minutes. Follow by laundering as normal.

Content.name: Save on Dry Cleaning
Content.description:
More Clean For Your Money

Trips to the dry cleaners are wildly inconvenient, especially when such a high price is paid for beloved pieces to be returned stiff and smelling of chemicals. That's why we recommend saving yourself both the inconvenience AND the money by washing at home! After all, 90% of items labeled "Dry Clean Only" are actually washable.
 

Handwashing vs. Dry Cleaning

   
 

Fabric Care Essentials For "Dry Clean Only" Items

   

1.Wool & Cashmere Shampoo

Our go-to for cleaning and preserving woolens. Your wool and cashmere items can and SHOULD be washed!

2. Wool & Cashmere Spray

Cedar is a natural moth repellent, so this multi-functional spray will protect woolens while rejuvenating sweaters, coats, and suits with a warm and spicy scent.

3. Delicate Wash

A formula gentle enough for commonly dry cleaned fabrics like silk, rayon, and acetate. Safe for handwashing and machine washing.

4. Wash Tub Basin

A removal rubber stopper and ridges for handwashing make this basin ideal for presoaking and washing garments.

5. Delicate Spray

Spritz a beautiful blend of rich amber, bergamot, lavender, and musk on garments to freshen between washes.

Content.name: When To Wash Your Woolens
Content.description:
When to Wash

Is your wool sweater in need of a full-fledged laundering session or will a spritz of fabric spray suffice?  

Our rule of thumb...

We suggest washing woolens after every 2 to 3 wears. Wool has natural odor resilience and water repellency properties, so sweaters won't absorb perspiration and body odors with one wear.  

Freshen Between Washes...

To remove any odors and freshen the garment's fibers, spritz with the Wool & Cashmere Spray. A nontoxic formula with anti-bacterial properties, this fabric spray will also ward off moths and critters with its cedar based scent. Brushing woolen garments with the Cashmere Brush between washes will also help rejuvenate yarns by releasing their natural oils and removing lingering lint, fuzz, and hair.  
 
Wool & Cashmere Spray | Cashmere Brush | Lavender Pouches | Scented Drawer Sheets | All Purpose Storage Bag

Content.name: Tips For Seasonal Storage
Content.description:
Bid your warm weather favorites farewell - for the next season or two that is! All that's required to ensure your crisp, white sundress or favorite pair of shorts are ready for wearing when the climate rises is to properly store. Have you ever noticed a yellow spot on a garment when unpacking? Perfume, body products and oils, food, and dirt often make themselves visible after a lapse of time making them MUCH more difficult to remove. Such residues also attract fabric-harmful critters such as moths and silverfish! How is one to prevent these inconvenient circumstances? Our Seasonal Storage Tips should help!  

1. Store Items Clean

Left over body products, oils, and perfumes as well as food and dirt will set in with time leaving stains and attracting critters!  

2. Fold or Hang According to Fabric Type

Delicate pieces and those prone to wrinkling are best stored folded with acid-free tissue. This practice is ideal for long term storage.   Do not hang knits, silks, or synthetics as this will alter the pieces' shape. Fur, leather, and outerwear are best stored hung. Improper storage of such pieces can result in their drying out which causes the loss of natural oils.   For cottons, linens, durable synthetics, and all fabrics to be stored folded, it is best to pack in a breathable fabric, such as cotton or linen, with a zip closure. Add a Lavender Pouch or Scented Drawer Sheet in Cedar to the storage bag to ward off bugs & moths and keep your clothing smelling sweet.      

3. Pick the Proper Storage Space

Pieces should be stored in a clean, dark, and dry area.  

4. Seasonally Re-organize

If you don't seasonally store your garments, doing a thorough re-organization one to two times a year is essential. Clean out closets, dressers, and drawers by removing all items from inside and vacuuming. Before restoring the clothing to their drawers, launder everything!  

Storing No - No's

Do not store items that are starched - moths LOVE starch. Never store in plastic or cardboard - these materials tend to attract bugs and encourage their reproduction. Do not use drawer liners or contact paper - adhesive attracts bugs as well! Do not store in attics or basements - humid/damp areas are optimal environments for moth breeding, mold, and mildew. Do not store in extreme temperatures - this will damage textiles. Do not store in direct sunlight - the fading and deteriorating fabrics will most likely occur. Do not store with moth balls - they are toxic and deadly. Not to mention their odor is impossible to remove. Do not store with cedar wood blocks or chips - they can transfer oil to fabric which stains clothing.  

Responding to Mold & Mildew

If mold or mildew does make a presence on your wardrobe, worry not as such pieces can usually be salvaged. The Stain Solution, Stain Brush, and Scented Vinegar are our go-to for mold removal. For step-by-step treating instructions, view our How To Treat Mold & Mildew. Remember, time is of the essence!  

Responding to Silverfish, Moths, & Bugs

To prevent silverfish, moth, and bug attacks, we recommend storing with a Lavender Pouch or Scented Drawer Sheet in Cedar as both cedar and lavender are natural bug repellents. Cleaning and storing properly is helpful as well! If your closet has been attacked by critters, you'll need to quarantine the scene! View our Bug & Moth Prevention and Treatment steps.

Content.name: How To Remove Chocolate Stains
Content.description:
Chocolate bars look oh-so delicious in with their glittering foil wrappers but not so appealing when melted all over your clothing (or Halloween costume)! As there lies a sweet tooth in us all, we are all too familiar with the struggle of both successfully and unsuccessfully lifting this rich, tannin stain. With Halloween coming up, we are dishing out our go-to tips for removing chocolate stains to add to your bag of tricks and treats!
Apply Stain Solution directly to the chocolate mark. If the stain is large or particularly difficult, sprinkle All-Purpose Bleach Alternative onto the Stain Solution. Pour boiling water from a height onto the mixture to activate the Bleach Alternative beads. Work the mixture into the fabric with a Stain Brush to create a powerful cleaning paste. Soak the item in a bath of hot water for up to 30 minutes.*  
Apply Stain Solution directly to the soiled area. Work the solution into the stain with a Stain Brush. For added cleaning power, hold the stain under a faucet running tepid water to help work in the solution. Soak the item in a bath of tepid water for no longer than 30 minutes.*  
Apply Stain Solution directly to the affected area. Work the solution into the fabric with your finger. If the item has looser yarns, use the Wash & Stain Bar to work the solution into the yarn. Hold the area being treated under a faucet running tepid water for added cleaning power. Soak the item in a bath of tepid water for up to 30 minutes.* *If the stain isn't removed at the soak's completion, repeat the pretreat process! It often times takes two to three pretreats to fully lift chocolate stains. Finish by laundering as normal.

Content.name: How To Care for Wool Rugs & Blankets
Content.description:
The season of dinner parties and social gatherings galore is among us. Don't let a wine spill on your wool rug or a smudge of chocolate on your throw distract you from the evening. With high amounts of wear from day to day use, chances are that these items are in need of close attention and care regardless of staining! Consider your blankets and rugs cleaned with our spot treating and care tips...  

Grease & oil-based stains

  • Wet the Wash & Stain Bar with tepid water and gently work it into the soiled area.
  • Lift the stain by dabbing the area with a Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth. Do not use paper towels or certain sponges because they may leave behind residue.
  • Remove soap and dirt by wetting another cloth and wiping the area clean.
  • Repeat the process until satisfied.

Dirt, wine, and tannin stains

  • Apply Stain Solution directly to the soiled area and gently work it in with your finger or a Stain Brush.
  • Remove soap by wetting a Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth and wiping away suds and stains.
  • Repeat the process until satisfied.
 

Makeup, lotions, and oil-based stains

  • Pretreat the affected area with the Wash & Stain Bar, lathering the bar with tepid water and gently working it into the fabric.
  • Soak the blanket or throw in a bath of cool water and leave to soak for roughly 30 minutes.
  • Finish by machine washing with Wool & Cashmere Shampoo on the delicate/woolens cycle in cold water. Lay flat to dry.

Chocolate, wine, coffee, and tannin stains

  • Pretreat the affected area with the Stain Solution, applying it directly to the stain and gently working it into the fabric.
  • Soak the blanket or throw in a bath of cool water and leave to soak for roughly 30 minutes.
  • Finish by machine washing with Wool & Cashmere Shampoo on the delicate/woolens cycle in cold water. Lay flat to dry.
 

Deodorize

  • Sprinkle All-Purpose Bleach Alternative beads onto the wool rug and vacuum clean.

Freshen

  • Steam wool rugs to rejuvenate fibers and kill bacteria and odor sources. The temperature of the steam will work to clean without damaging the fabric.
  • If possible, hang the rug outside where it can breathe. If the rug is too large to be moved outside, simply place it in a closed off room and open the windows.

Deodorize & Freshen

  • Deodorize and freshen wool blankets and throws between washes by spritzing with the Wool & Cashmere Spray. This formula not only has anti-bacterial properties, it's also scented in our beautiful Cedar scent.

Remove Lint & De-pill

  • Routinely brush wool blankets and throws with the Cashmere Brush to remove lint and rejuvenate the natural oils in the yarn.
  • For heavy-knit blankets, de-pill with the Sweater Stone gliding gently across the fabric.

Content.name: How To Care for Antique & Heirloom Linens
Content.description: While the holidays are a time for gifting (and receiving gifts!), we never lose sight of what truly makes this season "the most wonderful time of the year." Family and tradition are far merrier than any designer clutch or shade of lipstick after all! This holiday, bring tradition to the dinner table by laying out your heirloom linens - after giving them the right loving Laundress care, of course! STAINS: Pretreat stains and yellowing with Stain Solution and gently work it into the fabric. SOAK: Prepare a bath of hot water adding 2 capfuls of All-Purpose Bleach Alternative. Allow the item to soak and replace dirty water when necessary. Repeat until satisfied. PREPARE A "BATH": Fill a basin or sink with warm water and a squirt of Laundress detergent - Whites Detergent or Signature Detergent is recommended. SUBMERGE LINEN: Gently agitate the water so items will be evenly soaped and wet. Soak for at least 30 minutes. RINSE WELL: Run tepid water through the linen until rinse water is no longer soapy. Gently press the water out of the item. WASH: Select the delicate cycle and warm water temperature. Add the appropriate amount of Laundress detergent - Whites Detergent or Signature Detergent. TIP: We do not recommend using fabric softener with vintage or heirloom pieces. HANG TO DRY: Always hang to dry, never put in the dryer. Avoid direct sunlight and heat sources such as the radiator. DO NOT STARCH: Do not starch if returning the linens back to storage. Spritz with Crease Release to remove mild wrinkles. FRESHEN: Keep linens fresh between washes with Fabric Fresh Classic. *Please note that this process is recommended for cottons and linens. Items consisting of silk or silk-like synthetics may require different care instructions.

Content.name: R29: How Often Do You Need to Wash Your Jeans?
Content.description:
A new month brings a new dose of Laundress expertise to Refinery29! In this month's Contributor Network article, Gwen & Lindsey address one of the most debated topics in the world of laundry and fabric care - how and when to wash your jeans. While everyone has their own preference on the wear of their denim - wore-in and loose vs crisp and tight-fitting - The Laundress ladies have just the care instructions to satisfy jean aficionados of all types. From how often you should be washing to preserving color and fit, Gwen & Lindsey share their advice on achieving the best and most wear out of your favorite blue jeans (white denim included!)

Here's a little teaser of the R29 article...

"Is there any truth to the oft-believed idea that you don't have to wash jeans often? And, how often is often? This idea or concept is truly a personal preference. With our clients, we've noticed that men are much more inclined to avoid washing, in an effort to prevent fading and protect their "perfect, worn-in" feel. While women are also concerned with color and preserving their investment, laundering becomes imperative to redeem the fit/stretch of the jeans. If you prefer not to wash your denim regularly, we suggest a quick steam. Steaming will help to freshen denim and coupled withThe Laundress Fabric Fresh, will work to eliminate odor causing bacteria. However, with the appropriate knowledge and the right care products washing regularly is ok-- and is the preferred method by many!" Read the full article on Refinery29.com!

Remove and discard any loose food or debris. 2. For burned surfaces, soak the item in hot water and All-Purpose Bleach Alternative, scrubbing with the Copper Cloth. Do not use the Copper Cloth on teflon. 3. Follow by hand washing with Dish Detergent and hot water. 4. Rinse and wipe dry with a Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth. Caution: Copper materials are not dishwasher safe. Never place silver in the dishwasher with stainless steel or other metals--it will tarnish immediately. Avoid long term exposure to acidic liquids.

Content.name: How to Wash Down Coats
Content.description:
Braving the cold city streets or black diamond slopes soon? With the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo and Wool & Cashmere Spray on hand, we're predicting a fluffy, clean future for your down jacket! We captured Gwen washing her winter coat so that you can learn the step-by-step process!     Wool & Cashmere Shampoo, Wool & Cashmere Spray, Stain Solution, Wash & Stain Bar, Scented Vinegar, Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth, Stain Brush.   Lather the Wash & Stain Bar with tepid water and gently work it into the stained area. Wipe the area clean with a damp Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth. *If the stain has faded, but isn't completely gone, repeat the process until satisfied.   STAINS: Apply Stain Solution directly to the soiled area and gently work it into the fabric with your finger or a Stain Brush. *For added cleaning power, hold the stain beneath a faucet running tepid water. ODOR: Soak the item in a bath of tepid water and Scented Vinegar or add Scented Vinegar to the washing machine. Proceed with laundering.     Launder with Wool & Cashmere Shampoo selecting warm/cold water and the delicate/woolens cycle. *Front loading machines are preferred for washing down as they have a larger drum and no agitator.     Fill a large basin or bathtub with tepid water adding 2 capfuls of Wool & Cashmere Shampoo. Gently agitate the water with your hands and soak for roughly 30 minutes. Rinse well and gently press out excess water.   Machine dry on low heat, low tumble. Add clean tennis balls to the dryer to redistribute feathers and down filling. *Use caution when machine drying large down items - they can get overheated and clog vents which can be a fire hazard.    
  • Down jackets should be washed once a season and always before seasonal storage.
  • An alternative to machine drying is airing outside and line drying - it's most effective for anti-bacterial purposes.
  • Steam to remove mites and allergens.
  • Spritz Wool & Cashmere Spray between washes to freshen.
  • Never iron or starch.
  • Never dryclean.
  • Never treat with chlorine bleach.
  Click here for additional Down How Tos! Think duvets, feather beds & pillows...

Content.name: Before & After | Stained Napkins
Content.description:
Grand holiday feasts leave napkins and table linens decorated with the most colorful of stains.

  From red wine spills to splashes of gravy, the All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and Stain Solution can help restore your linens to their clean, pristine selves ...ensuring the whitest and brightest of Christmases for you and your holiday guests.   All-Purpose Bleach Alternative, Stain Solution, Stain Brush, Whites Detergent   1. Apply products: Apply Stain Solution directly to the affected area. For stubborn or large stains, strengthen the formula by sprinkling All-Purpose Bleach Alternative on the solution to create a powerful paste. 2. Work the stain: Work the solution into the fabric using your finger or Stain Brush. [one_half][/one_half] [one_half_last]3. Pour water on the stain: For added cleaning power, pour boiling water from a kettle onto the affected area. You can also use water from a faucet set to its highest water pressure output. 4. Soak up to 30 minutes: Soak the item in a basin filled with hot water. 5. Repeat as needed: If the stain is not completely gone, repeat this process until satisfied. [/one_half_last]   [one_half]6. Launder: Launder in hot water with Whites Detergent. 7. Content.name: How To Clean On The Go
Content.description:
Traveling for the holidays? Let us help you keep your wardrobe clean & wrinkle-free...

  Always carry a Wash & Stain Bar! Compact enough to comfortably fit in your purse, clutch, backpack, or briefcase, the Wash & Stain Bar is perfect for spot treating stains right when they happen! This preventative measure will save you time when treating back at home. Simply lather the Wash & Stain Bar and soiled area of the garment with water and gently work the bar into the fabric. Follow by wiping the suds clean with a damp, lint-free cloth. When you return home, treat again with either the Wash & Stain Bar or Stain Solution and launder as normal once satisfied with stain removal. Whether traveling by plane, train, or automobile, the Travel Pack includes everything needed to keep your clothing tidy and fresh. Remove stains from business dinners, wash your favorite camisole, freshen your hotel room, and release suitcase wrinkles with our travel-sized items. Lindsey's trick for steaming sans-steamer is a lifesaver! Simply turn the hotel's iron to the steam setting and lightly graze the hanging fabric. Finish by spraying Crease Release on the garment to expel any withstanding creases and not a wrinkle will be left in sight!

Content.name: The Ultimate Holiday Helper
Content.description: Decorating the Christmas tree, blushing beneath the mistletoe, playing footsie in fuzzy stockings, and warming the room with candles are all festive activities that we look forward to year round. Holiday favorites can yield uh-oh moments, but with us as the Holiday Helper your only worry should be whether Santa's deemed you naughty or nice! Did a visit beneath the mistletoe leave blush on your shoulder or lipstick on your collar? Lather Santa's Stain Bar with tepid water and gently work it into the makeup stain to remove all traces of naughtiness! Dashing store to store? Remove mud and touch up your patent leather pumps with the Glass & Mirror Cleaner. Spray, wipe, and repeat! A girl can never have too many shopping trips when there's gift to be bought and stocking to be filled! Trimming and decorating the tree never fails to gift a stain that is oh-so stubborn. Rub the tree sap with an ice cube and gently scrape off excess sap. Follow by applying a water-lathered Santa's Stain Bar to the stain and laundering as normal. Whether you were playing footsie in stockings or just a victim to the dryness of winter, static cling is a common annoyance. Banish static by spraying Static Solution in between socks and cloths. Don't have the spray handy? Simply wet your hands and wipe between the layers. Hot, liquid wax can be cleaned off quickly with a blow dryer or hand dryer. Hardened, solid wax should be ironed with a cloth between the fabric and the iron. Pretreat with Stain Solution and launder as normal. If your top has be anointed with a splatter of dressing, ask your host(ess) for table salt, cornstarch, or baby powder to lift the stain. After the dinner party, treat further with Stain Solution and launder as normal. Read this article on the J. Crew blog as well!

Content.name: Detox Your Home For The New Year
Content.description:
Detoxes call for flushing out the negative, the harmful, and the toxic to achieve a state of renewal, rejuvenation, and cleanliness.

Think that this can only be achieved in your diet? Think again!

With the Laundress' plant-derived, nontoxic, and allergen-free home cleaning collection, you can make your home environment feel just as cleansed. Five multi-purpose cleaning products are all it takes to transform your cleaning routine into a green one.   [one_half]All-Purpose Bleach Alternative is 100% sodium percarbonate, chlorine-free, and oxygen based, making it family, pet, and food safe. Formulated without artificial dye, it's also color friendly![/one_half][one_half_last]Chlorine Bleach contains blue dye for colorant and hydrogen peroxide which agitates skin. Not to mention, its scent is strong and abrasive.[/one_half_last] [one_half]Glass & Mirror Cleaner contains streak-free cleaning enhancers derived from corn. Its sans-fragrance formula ensures residue-free results and high performance glucoside effortlessly removes dirt and grime.[/one_half][one_half_last]Traditional Glass Cleaners have minimal to no cleaning enhancers and contain derivatives of formaldehyde as a wetting agent. Not only is this harmful to skin and eyes, it's also hazardous to the environment. Artificial dyes can also leave behind residue and stain fabrics.[/one_half_last] [one_half]All-Purpose Cleaning Concentrate is composed of plant-derived anionic and nonionic surfactants for optimal cleaning performance. The soil dispersant sodium gluconate boosts cleaning power and its No247 fragrance makes it pleasurable to the senses.[/one_half][one_half_last]Toilet Bowl Cleaners contain hydrogen chloride which is known to be corrosive to eyes and skin.[/one_half_last] [one_half]Scented Vinegar is our corn derived, 100% natural vinegar. Known for its powerful cleaning properties that fight buildup, odor, and germs, vinegar's all-natural cleaning properties combined with the two-ply copper threads of the Copper Cloth will leave your oven flawless. [/one_half][one_half_last]Traditional Oven Cleaner contains sodium hydroxide and ethanol both of which are immediate hazards upon contact and are deemed hazardous substances in numerous states. These harsh ingredients can damage aluminum and painted surfaces as well.[/one_half_last] [one_half]Home Spray freshens the room with minimal ingredients- deionized water, alcohol, essential oils, and fragrance. Completely free of phosphates and allergen causing materials, the Home Spray has antibacterial properties and is safe on fabrics![/one_half][one_half_last]Common Air Fresheners tend to contain sodium phosphate which causes skin irritation and negatively impacts surface water, not to mention their scents are often overbearing.[/one_half_last]

Content.name: Winter Sport Outerwear Care
Content.description:
Suiting up for winter sports means that you're covered from head to toe in MULTIPLE layers! Whether you're an expert skier taking on black diamonds, a novice snowboarder falling down one too many times, or simply a fan of frolicking through a fresh snowfall, you'll most certainly be sporting fundamental outerwear pieces. From a heavy duty jacket and snow pants to gloves, we have just the tips to help keep your outwear clean and looking cool. Did we mention that you can care for all of your winter sport outerwear using the same steps?! Sport Detergent, Sport Spray, Stain Solution, Stain Brush, Mesh Bag

Pretreat:

Apply Stain Solution directly to stains and/or stain prone areas. Such areas include: cuffs, hemlines, and palm patches for gloves. Work in the solution with a Stain Brush or finger.  

Did you know?

It's safe to treat leather palm patches on gloves. They're crafted to withstand the harshest of elements after all! [one_half] [/one_half][one_half_last]

Prepare to wash:

Turn items inside out and insert into a Mesh Bag to protect zippers and hardware during the wash cycle.

Machine wash:

Select the delicate cycle. Make sure that the water temperature is cold and the spin is medium to low. Add the appropriate amount of Sport Detergent according to the machine and load size.[/one_half_last] It's safe to wash outerwear of like-colors together! [one_half]

Dry:

Lay the items flat in their natural shape on a drying rack. When drying, avoid direct sunlight and heat sources such as the radiator. [/one_half][one_half_last][/one_half_last]

Freshen:

Keep items fresh between wearing and washing with Sport Spray. It's perfect for removing odor after a long day on the slopes! You can steam to freshen as well.

Content.name: How To Wash Hosiery
Content.description:
In light of our collaboration with fine hosiery brand Wade + Belle (which happens to be Gwen & Lindsey's favorite line of tights!), we thought it would be helpful to share how to properly care for these very delicate, yet very practical pieces. From handwashing vs machine washing to making elasticity last, we're giving you a leg up on laundering hosiery! [one_half] [/one_half] [one_half_last]
  • Before laundering, treat any stains with Stain Solution or the Wash & Stain Bar. We like to use the stain bar to work deep dirt areas.
  • To remove odor, soak the item for up to 30 minutes in tepid water mixed with cup of Scented Vinegar. You may apply a small amount of vinegar directly to the target area, then wash.
[/one_half_last] [one_half]Handwashing is the best and safest way to care for delicate tights and hosiery. This will protect the fabric's color and elasticity!
  • Fill a wash basin or sink with tepid water and add 2 capfuls or a squirt of Delicate Wash.
  • Soak for at least 30 minutes.
[/one_half][one_half_last] [/one_half_last] [one_half][/one_half] [one_half_last]
  • Rinse well, running room temperature water over the item until the rinse water is no longer soapy.
  • Do not wring. Instead, press the item against the sink or basin to remove the water.
[/one_half_last]   [one_half]
  • Select the delicate cycle and cold water temperature on the washing machine.
  • To avoid tangling or snagging, insert into a Mesh Washing Bag.
  • Add the appropriate amount of Delicate Wash.
[/one_half] [one_half_last] [/one_half_last] *Please note that machine washing exposes hosiery to lint which may make the color duller.   [one_half] [/one_half][one_half_last]
  • Hang to dry or lay item(s) flat on a drying rack.
  • Spray with Delicate Spray between wearing and washing to freshen.
[/one_half_last]

Content.name: Don't be the Fool with Pills on her Cashmere
Content.description: PureWow recently published KNIT WIT | How to Get Pills Off a Sweater - which is a problem near and dear to our hearts! Check out the article below for some de-pilling home remedies.

Content.name: Before & After | Removing Mystery Stains
Content.description: If you toasted your way into the New Year, your evening ensemble may be marked with an unidentifiable stain or two! Whether it be champagne or sparkling cider, we have a cheers-worthy remedy that is perfect for that Little Black Dress - and it's safe for numerous fabric types!   Fabric : Polyester with beaded embellishment Problem : Mystery stains down the front 1. Apply Stain Solution directly to any mystery stains and problem areas. 2. Follow by gently working the Wash & Stain Bar into the fabric. 3. Work the stain with a Stain Brush. 4. Next, fill a wash basin or sink with tepid water and add 2 capfuls or a squirt of Delicate Wash. This garment's embellishments require handwashing with Delicate Wash. 5. Gently agitate the water and allow the item to soak for 10-15 minutes. If treating silk or silk-like synthetics, soaking for 10-15 minutes is ideal. For this dress, we left the top half out of the water to protect beading beneath the bust. 6. At the soak's completion, rinse well until soapy water runs clear. We followed with an additional cleanse in fresh water, this time submerging the entire garment. This was required as not to cause a difference in color between the top and bottom half. 7. Hang to dry or machine dry if applicable.

Content.name: Product Spotlight | Fabric Conditioner
Content.description:
Updating your laundry room in 2015? Don't forget to include the fabric softener! Made with natural ingredients, our plant-derived Fabric Conditioner softens bedding and clothing while decreasing drying time and reducing both wrinkles and static cling. Working throughout the wash cycle, you can skip the dyer sheets later on! Effective in all water temperatures, simply add the Conditioner directly into the softener dispenser to fluff up cottons and linens and bake in the scent of either Classic, No.10 or Baby. What's the main difference between the Fabric Conditioner and generic grocery store brands? Ours is canola-based while others often contain animal fat that coats fabrics and is difficult to remove.

Tips to know!

  • Avoid using softeners on towels as absorbency can reduce over time.
  • Do not use on children's sleepwear as it can reduce flame retardency.
  • Do not use on woolens, silks, or synthetics.

Content.name: The Laundress for J. Crew
Content.description:
...Don't Dry Clean Your Cashmere!

The Laundress and J. Crew share a special love for fine cashmere, so it only makes sense that when it comes to providing the utmost care for these beloved pieces we have it down to a science. Only the cream of the crop can be trusted on these delicate fibers and both brands deliver this luxury.   While the names are slightly different, The Laundress Wool & Cashmere Shampoo vs J. Crew Cashmere Wash, the formula and end effect are one in the same - each safely cleans and preserves natural fibers, eliminating the need for dry cleaning. What's the difference then? The scent! The namesake product is scented in Cedar, a modern take on the traditional woody scent. Lavender is the predominant note in the J. Crew Cashmere Wash.   Not quite sure whether or not you're ready for your sweaters to take the big plunge? Let Gwen and Lindsey lead the way...

Content.name: How To Wash Winter Accessories
Content.description:
It's a fact: we simply couldn't survive the cold winter months without the cozy accessories we layer on each time we leave our homes! Helping us bear the chilly weather day-in and day-out, our hats, scarves, and gloves will eventually be due for some much-needed TLC. Whether it be removing pills from your favorite cashmere piece or lifting makeup stains from the inside of your hat, we've got you covered!
  • Before laundering, pretreat any stains with either the Stain Solution or Wash & Stain Bar.
  • The Wash & Stain Bar is ideal for removing grease-based stains like foundation, lotion, and other beauty products that may be left behind on hats and scarves!
  Handwashing is the safest way to care for wool and cashmere items. When in doubt - handwash! [one_half]
  • Fill a washing basin or sink with cool or tepid water.
  • Add 2 capfuls of Wool & Cashmere Shampoo and mix into the water.
  • Turn the item inside out - if a hat or gloves - and submerge into the bath.
  • Soak the item for up to 30 minutes.
[/one_half][one_half_last] [/one_half_last]
  • Rinse well under tepid water until soapy water runs clear.
  • Do not wring. Instead, gently press the item against the sink or basin to remove excess water.
You can machine wash most woolen hats, scarves, and gloves using a delicate, woolens, or hand wash cycle selecting cold water. [one_half][/one_half] [one_half_last]
  • Turn the item inside out and insert into a Mesh Washing Bag. This will keep smaller items together - i.e. gloves - during the wash cycle and prevent any snagging or tangling in the machine.
  • Select the woolens cycle and cold/cold on the machine.
  • Add the appropriate amount of Wool & Cashmere Shampoo.
[/one_half_last]
  • Never put woolen accessories in the dryer!
  • Lay items flat in their natural shape on top of a flat drying rack or towel.
Pilling is a direct result of wearing, so with much wear comes many pills!
  • Fine gauge woolens (thin, cashmere gloves): Gently glide the Sweater Comb in one direction across the pilled area.
  • Heavier woolens (thick, chunky scarves): Drag the Sweater Stone in one direction across the pilled area.
  • Spray with the Wool & Cashmere Spray between wearing and washing to keep items smelling fresh.
  • Remove lint, fuzz, and hair with the Cashmere Brush. Brushing will release natural oils that rejuvenate yarns.

Content.name: The Laundress is Mom Candy
Content.description: Mom.Me featured The Laundress in Mom Candy January | A daily look at our latest obsessions - we're Friday's Daily Pick! Click through below to see our No. 10 Laundry Detergent along with the rest of the week's must-haves.

Content.name: Flash Sale on Home Cleaning Products

Content.name: How to Care for Non-Washable Fur
Content.description:
One of the most beloved investment pieces in everyone's wardrobe is a stunning fur/faux fur coat or vest. While caring for these pieces is difficult and should be left to the professionals, you can maintain your furs throughout the season with a quick and effortless care routine - NO dry cleaner needed!

Fur with skin:

We never recommend washing fur that has skin on the underside as the skin can shrink or dry out if wet.

Vintage fur:

Older fur is often brittle and frail and can disintegrate during the wash process. That being said, we don't suggest washing - only freshening!

Fur without skin:

Fur that is knitted or lacks an attached skin can often times be beautifully washed! We always advise to handwash at your own risk, however as there is potential for dye bleeding and change in the fur's hand. We've had both excellent and disagreeable experiences with washing such pieces in our own laundry rooms. If you do decide to take the plunge, you can try doing so with Wool & Cashmere Shampoo. [one_half]Appropriate for treating light spills and stains on both washable and non-washable furs.
  • Lather the Wash & Stain Bar with tepid water and gently work it into the stain and fur.
  • Follow by wiping the suds clean with a damp Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth.
[/one_half][one_half_last][/one_half_last] Appropriate for all fur types.
  • Keep furs conditioned and soft by spraying the garment with Crease Release before each wear.
  • Deodorize and freshen with a fabric spray between wears. A complex blend of sinister spice and fresh powdery notes, the No.10 Fabric Fresh is the perfect accomplice.
  • Brush regularly with the Cashmere Brush to rejuvenate the furs' natural oils and remove lint and hair.
  • Seasonally store fur pieces in cold temperatures - any temperature below 55 degrees Fahrenheit is ideal.
  • Humidity should be controlled between 45 to 55%.
  • Light exposure should be minimal.
  • Never store in cedar closets or garment bags or with moth balls.
For additional fur care tips, please visit Fur Information Council of America (FICA) or Authorized Fur Care Specialist. If you're interested in DIY cleaning, we recommend reading this helpful article! Considering glazing your fur? Read Guide to Glazing.

Content.name: Clean Stinky Washing Machines
Content.description: If your front-loader or HE washing machine has been in overdrive to clean off winter grime, you may be smelling the not-so-sweet scent of mildew. Cleaning your machine regularly with hot water and a mix of All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and Scented Vinegar will remedy this issue in no time at all! *Front-loading machines are highly prone to mildew because they experience build-up of water, detergent, and dirt that collects in the cavity holding the washing drum. Add 1/2 cup of Scented Vinegar and 2 capfuls of All-Purpose Bleach Alternative to the machine dispenser and run an EMPTY, long load with hot water. Repeat again with hot water only. Clean out fabric softener & bleach dispensers as well! Please note: All-Purpose Bleach Alternative should be added directly to machine drum or detergent dispenser, do NOT add to bleach dispenser.  We recommend leaving the door open when not in use to air out the machine. Cleaning the washing machine monthly with All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and Scented Vinegar will also work to remove lime scale, rust, and build-up caused by iron and calcium. If left untreated, these minerals will leave behind spots and make the machine work harder raising energy bills up to 25%. The dryer drum collects lint which can leave fuzz behind on clean clothing and affect the efficiency of the dryer over time. Wipe down the inside of the dryer regularly with a lint-free cloth and mixture of 1 capful of Stain Solution and 1 liter of water. This will help to remove lint. Clean the dryer filter after each use as a clogged filter will restrict flow and reduce dryer performance. It's also a MAJOR fire hazard.

Dinginess

Caused by buildup of fiber, minerals in wash water, soap residue, or body oils.

Brighten + Whiten

Cotton, linen & durable synthetics: Presoak in a bath of hot water mixed with 1 capful of All-Purpose Bleach Alternative for at least 30 minutes. Launder as normal in hot water with Whites Detergent. Silk & silk-like synthetics: Presoak in a bath of tepid water and cup of Scented Vinegar for no more than 30 minutes. Launder as normal in cool water and Delicate Wash. Wool, cashmere, blends & wool-like synthetics: Presoak in a bath of cool water and cup of Scented Vinegar for no longer than 30 minutes. Launder as normal in cool water and Wool & Cashmere Shampoo.

Prevent Dinginess

- Avoid fiber buildup by washing towels separate from clothing. - Don't use powdered detergents. - If you have hard water, add 1 capful of All-Purpose Bleach Alternative to the wash load with the detergent (only applicable for cottons, linens, and durable synthetics.) - For silks and woolens, add cup for Scented Vinegar to the wash load every once in a while.

Content.name: How To Launder Bugaboo Footmuffs
Content.description:
A Stroll in the Park

Footmuffs keep baby snug and happy during winter outings. Bugaboo footmuffs keep us parents equally content - cleaning them is a total stroll in the park! As the spilling of formula, milk, and food are a common occurrence, these stroller inserts require frequent laundering. Washing once a month or whenever heavily soiled is recommended. From fleece to down, we have the best (and easiest) start to finish care instructions to keep inserts clean and cuddly for baby.
    Identify stains on both the interior and exterior of the footmuff prior to washing.    
  • Apply Stain Solution directly to any soiled areas.
  • For tough or set-in stains, sprinkle All-Purpose Bleach Alternative* onto the Stain Solution to create a powerful cleaning paste.
  • Use a Stain Brush to gently work this paste into the fabric.
*All-Purpose Bleach Alternative should not be used on woolens, silk, or leather.    
  • Fully zip all zippers and snap all buttons to wash. This will prevent tangling or snagging while in the machine.
  • Insert into a Mesh Bag to protect hardware during the wash cycle. This step is not required, just recommended however.

For Fleece

  • Set the machine to the normal cycle and select a warm/cold water temperature and medium spin.
  • If the machine has an adjustable soil level, set to heavy for the most thorough clean.
  • Add two capfuls or a squirt of Baby Detergent to the detergent dispenser or directly into the machine drum.

For Down

  • Set the machine to the delicate or woolens cycle and select a warm/cold water temperature and low spin.
  • If the machine has an adjustable soil level, set to heavy for the most thorough clean.
  • Add two capfuls or a squirt of Wool & Cashmere Shampoo to the detergent dispenser or directly into the machine drum.
  For down footmuffs, tumble dry, low heat until completely dry to prevent water marks. For fleece items, lay flat to dry.

Content.name: Clean Green on St. Patrick's Day!
Content.description:
Here at The Laundress, we're celebrating St. Patrick's Day by giving a nod to all things green - including our laundry detergents! As each detergent and stain remover is formulated with natural, plant-derived ingredients, you can thoughtfully (and safely) care for you clothing at home without exposing yourself to harmful dry cleaning chemicals. But what about "Dry Clean Only" pieces? Through extensive research and testing, we've found that 90% of our wardrobes can and should be washed! Not only is skipping the dry cleaner a more eco-friendly practice, but it will save you money and help preserve clothing as well!  
  Dry cleaning often leaves clothing feeling stiff and rigid and smelling of chemicals. Over time, this treatment can deteriorate the integrity of the fabric and strip fibers of their natural oils. What's more is the staining and yellowing of a garment can actually be set-in during this process rather than removed! Most dry cleaners use a standard solvent called perchloreothylene or perc for stain removal and treatment. This solution is "a central nervous system depressant, and is listed as a hazardous air pollutant under the federal standards."* Not to mention, it's also used in paint strippers, spot removers, and solvent-based household products. If a visit to the dry cleaner is simply unavoidable, try seeking one that uses a liquid carbon dioxide treatment. This treatment is used in high-pressure cleaning machines and achieves the best results.* Did you know that 300 million dry cleaning bags are added to landfills each year?* *Check out Treehugger.com for more on Green Dry Cleaning!  
  All products are made with nontoxic, biodegradable, and allergen-free materials. Each consists of natural ingredients. Color and texture may vary. Content.name: Before & After | Cleaning Grout & Tile
Content.description:
Get ready for April "showers" by giving your bathroom tiles a nice, deep clean. Whether you're experiencing staining, soap scum, or lime scale buildup, the solution is the same. The highly-effective (and completely nontoxic) combination of All-Purpose Cleaning Concentrate and All-Purpose Bleach Alternative will banish tile blemishes in a breeze. Clean weekly to help make the process easier! If you're not maintaining regularly, you might find yourself in the below situation... In this before & after, a shower drain was clogged for a week which lead to unsightly soap scum buildup. To unclog and remove, we opted for a natural remedy.   Mix 1 cup of boiling Scented Vinegar with cup of All-Purpose Bleach Alternative. Pour this mixture into the drain and let sit for 5 minutes. Finish by rinsing well with hot water. Completely effective, yet completely safe! Many grocery-brand drain cleaners contain harsh, toxic chemicals that are dangerous when in contact with skin and leave behind a pungent odor. Not exactly ideal to be using where one bathes... S T E P 1 | Mix All-Purpose Cleaning Concentrate with hot water in a bucket (or right in the shower!) S T E P 2 | Sprinkle the All-Purpose Bleach Alternative directly onto the surface and let it sit for a few minutes. S T E P 3 | Use the Scrub Brush to clean and remove soap scum and staining. S T E P 4 | Rinse well to remove excess soap. Lingering suds can leave areas slippery!    

All-Purpose Bleach Alternative | All-Purpose Cleaning Concentrate | Scented Vinegar | Scrub Brush

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I'm looking for a static-reducing spray for a friend with asthma. What is source of fragrance for your products: natural or chemical? Is your spray non-aerosol?
Content.description:
Dear Janet- Our Static Solution is a non-aerosol, liquid pump. While all of our fragrance is composed of natural oils, we can't guarantee the effect it may have on someone with asthma.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- What ingredients are in the Crease Release? I have sensitive skin and need to know before I purchase it!
Content.description:
Dear Elle- The active ingredient in the Crease Release is silicone, which works to relax the fibers. The Crease Release should be sprayed directly onto the fabric, not to the skin. I hope this helps!
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Do your products contain any animal-based ingredients? Do you test your products on animals?
Content.description:
Dear Caroline- We don't test on animals nor use animal ingredients in our products. Each of our products proudly states this fact on its label!
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Can I use the Baby Detergent to handwash a few delicate items?
Content.description:
Dear Brennan- Yes- you can use the Baby Detergent for hand and machine washing. It is fine for delicate items, however I recommend using the L-005 in the future.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I do laundry at the laundrymat and most don't have single load machines. For double load washing machines, should I add 1/2 cup detergent?
Content.description:
Dear Shavonne- Yes, you will want to use double the amount for the larger machines. Our product is rather concentrated so only use more if you fill the machines.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Are your detergents non-toxic and do they contain phosphates?
Content.description:
Dear Sarah- All of our products are phosphate-free and bio-degradable. We also do not use any artificial coloring or dyes.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Are your detergents --the Whites Detergent in particular-- safe for septic tanks?
Content.description:
Dear Beth- Absolutely. All of our detergents are 100% bio-degradable.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I love how you products smell, but would like to know if you use all natural ingredients, or if there are chemicals in them?
Content.description:
Dear Jennifer- We are glad that you enjoy our line! All of our products are sulfate, phosphate, and caustic-free and are 100% bio-degradable. We also do not use any dyes.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- How heavily fragranced are your detergents? I have extremely sensitive skin, and heavy perfumes can cause a reaction.
Content.description:
Dear Marlena- Our Classic fragrance is the strongest scent, however we haven't had any issues with our fragrances causing reactions. Many people who have a family member with allergies have success with our Baby scent which blends vanilla, musk, lily of the valley, lavender and sandalwood.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I would like to confirm that your products are all Gluten-Free. Also is there risk for gluten cross contamination?
Content.description:
Dear Barbara- We do not have gluten present in our detergent formulas nor in our fragrances. To the best of our knowledge, gluten is not present and all of our products are produced in clean and sterile environments that are not contaminated.
Please see the below statement for our Scented Vinegar:
PRESENCE OF GLUTEN IN WHITE DISTILLED VINEGAR Since gluten is one of the proteins in wheat and other grains and is left behind when starch is converted to sugar, there is a possibility that vinegar made from non-distilled grain-sourced alcohol might contain gluten. However, as any grain-sourced alcohol used by Laboratory, Inc for making white distilled vinegar is triple-distilled, to the best of our knowledge, no gluten is present.
To the best of our knowledge and within the limitations of standard fermentation technology, all vinegar we supply to the industry is consistent in process and raw material content.

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have an HE washing machine thus I am supposed to use only the HE formulas. How does this pertain to your formulas?
Content.description:
Dear Lisa- Our product is suitable for HE machines if you use half the amount of our recommended quantity. We suggest using 1/4 cup per wash which would equate to 1/8th of a cup when washing in an HE washing machine.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- My front load washing machine instructs not to use bleach. Is your Whites Detergent safe to use in my machine? If so, will it damage the elastic in my fitted sheets?
Content.description:
Dear Laura- The Whites Detergent does not have bleach and will not harm the fabric nor the elasticity of your sheets.
Repetitive use of bleach will wear on the fabric, however. I put my hand right through my fitted sheets after using too much bleach!
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- How much detergent do I use for my front load washing machine? Which detergent do you recommend I use for my sheets and towels?
Content.description:
Dear Linda- If you have a normal machine, use of a cup. If you have an HE machine use 1/8th of a cup.
When washing sheets and towels, you should choose whichever product best caters to them. For example, if you sheets and towles are white, you should purchase the Whites Detergent.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I keep hearing that optical brighteners are awful for people and harsh on the fabrics. A sales associate in a high-end linen store also told me not to wash my newly purchased towels or sheets in detergents that contain optical brighteners. What do you think?
Content.description:
Dear Patricia- This is really personal preference. We use optical brighteners in our Whites Detergent because it's more effective and less harsh than bleach. In the long run, it isn't going to ruin most fabrics.Optical brighteners are not harmful to people in relation to the clothing and skin and it's bio-degradable.
While there are some environmental debates concerning optical brighteners, there are worse ingredients used in grocery brand detergents which are petroleum- based.
We formulate our Signature Detergent, Darks Detergent, and Delicate Wash without it, however.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I am interested in purchasing the C-006 and was wondering what the surfactants are derived from. In particular, I avoid Sodium Laureth or Laurly Sulfate (SLS) products because they are endocrine disruptors.
Content.description: Dear Donna- None of our products contain Sodium Laurel Sulfate (SLS). However, they do contain Sodium Laureth Sulfate (SLES). This is coconut based, a non-irritant, and a gentle cleaning agent.

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Is your Whites Detergent appropriate to use if I have iron in my water?
Content.description:
Dear Mary- Our products are safe to use with any water source. The Whites Detergent is excellent for brightening whites and our S-001 is a must for all-purpose laundering!
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a old christianing gown that is nearly 40 years old. It's yellowing and rusty-looking. I tried bleaching it, but the color stays the same. How can I make it white again?
Content.description:
Dear Gail- I am not surprised the bleach didn't work well, as bleach doesn't usually remove stains like these.
I've listed some stain removal methods below: - Apply Stain Solution directly to any particularly tough rust-like spots and gently work it into the fabric. For extra tough stains, sprinkle All-Purpose Bleach Alternative into the Stain Solution to create a powerful cleaning paste. - Boil water on the stove and add the gown to the pot. Make sure to stir the garment and let it simmer. - Follow with a machine wash using Whites Detergent. - Line dry in the sun.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a christening gown that is 27 years old. The care label on the slip says it's made of acrylic, but the dress appears to be nylon. After all these years, the articles have yellowed. What is your suggested method to whiten them without destroying the fabric?
Content.description:
Dear Dianne- Do not use bleach as it will further yellow nylon and acrylic. These fabrics can withstand heat, so I suggest boiling the gown in a large pot of water with a cup of white vinegar and treating the stained areas with Stain Solution and All-Purpose Bleach Alternative. Once this pretreat is complete, I recommend machine washing with the Whites Detergent on a delicate or hand washing cycle.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I just found a vintage, organdy christening dress. I believe it's 60 years old. It's in perfect shape except for discoloration - It's very yellow. How do I get the color brightened and whitened?
Content.description:
Dear Donna- Is the gown a cotton organdy? If so: - Apply Stain Solution directly to any stained areas and gently work it into the fabric. When dealing with more difficult stains, sprinkle some All-Purpose Bleach Alternative onto the Stain Solution to create a powerful cleaning paste. Put the gown in a boiling pot of water, adding a cup of whie vinegar to the bath. Turn off the heat and leave to soak. - Finish with a hand wash using the Whites Detergent.
**Do not bleach as this will make the yellowing worse!
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have some vintage fur stoles and collars with silk linings that need a good cleaning. I read on your blog that this can be done with Delicate Wash. However, Google articles claim that hand washing furs and immersing them in water will result in considerable shrinkage and will ruin the fur. Is this as safe as you say?
Content.description:
Dear Brianna- Thank you for reaching out. While we do not specialize in fur, we have tried and had some successes. We cannot guarantee that the below methods will work best for you, however. We ususally consult fur industry veteran Tom Moriber! I've provided a link to his site for you below. http://www.fureverfurs.com/v2/
We successfully wash fur trims and furs that are in a knitted form with Wool & Cashmere Shampoo. Saturating fur that is on the skin is a problem because the skin can shrink and/or become dry and brittle. Vintage fur is generally dry from age and climate as well as brittle and stinky.
Industrial fur cleaning is essentially putting the fur in a tumbler with a chemical and saw dust. Our DYI approach would be to sprinkle with cornstarch or powder, sit, and shake out well. A silicone-based, fur glaze is recommended for older furs to condition them. We use our Crease Release to spray and conditioner our furs. We also use our Fabric Fresh which is gentle and safe enough to use on fur while not damaging or drying the fur.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a vintage organza and cotton lace unlined dress. There is only slight yellowing on the standup neckline and the rest of the dress is dingy, but spotless. What should I do?
Content.description:
Dear Bonnie- I would first try and treat the yellow with the Wash & Stain Bar. Follow by hand washing with Delicate Wash and cold water. Since the dress is vintage, it will require multiple washings, rinsings, and soakings.
Our All-Purpose Bleach Alternative is the BEST for yellowing and dinginess, but not ideal for silk. If necesary, you could do an extremely quick soak in it. Just be mindful that it may damage the fibers if subjected to the bleach alternative for an extended amount of time.
For additional tips, please reference our Silks & Delicates and Antique & Heirloom recipes.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have some delicate vintage table linens that have developed some brownish tea-looking spots while stored. The linens were clean and pressed and over the last couple of years these spots have surfaced. Is it safe to attempt to bleach them?
Content.description:
Dear Barbara- We never recommend using chlorine bleach to launder your items, as the harsh chemicals can be damaging to fabrics.
