For added cleaning power, pour hot water from a height onto the stain to help work in the solution. If stain has faded, but isn't completely gone, repeat the process until satisfied. You can also try adding All-Purpose Bleach Alternative to the Stain Solution to make a cleaning paste, which will also need to be worked into the fabric. The bleach alternative should not be used on silks, woolens or leather.
- Wash: Launder with hot water and Whites Detergent which combines color guard and enzymes optical brightener. Add All-Purpose Bleach Alternative directly to the drum of the washing machine for added whitening.
-Dry: Press out the water, never wring or twist. Hang to dry and steam for best results. http://blog.thelaundress.com/wordpress/?s=recipe+stain+removal
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I sprayed sunscreen on my boys and some landed on my coffee table and it left spots everywhere.
Content.description:
Dear Cynthia, If spots were left on the table cloth, just soak it in hot/warm water with our Stain Solution and launder. Make sure all marks are gone before putting in the dryer or ironing. Sometimes oily bases need a few soakings.
If the spots were left on a table, I would suggest Murphy's oil soap and a bit of olive oil.
Best The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I've read the section on getting the infamous pit stain out of white shirts. Does this also work for brightening white items in general such as white dish towels that get stains from repeated use? Would the same formula be appropriate in this case?
Content.description:
Dear Holly- I recommend the same process when treating stains on the towels. You can also do a boiling session with white vinegar too.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I was given a bunch of 50s tablecloths of my mom's that have stains on them, mostly coffee stains. I do not want to ruin them, and was wondering if there was way to bring them back to better state. They are otherwise not terribly worn.
Content.description:
Dear Sharon- For these stains, we'd recommend using our Stain Solution. The Stain Solution is formulated specifically for coffee and other tannin stains, like red wine or blood. It is gentle to use on any fabric and won't harm the vintage tablecloths.
Most of these tablecloths are cotton, linen or polyester. In this case, you can presoak with our All-Purpose Bleach Alternative. It is color safe and will work to get rid of any dinginess. Follow by laundering with our Signature Detergent.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- How can I remove candle wax from a tablecloth?
Content.description:
Dear Nancy, Try to pick off what you can and place a thin cloth over the wax and iron repeatedly to lift the wax from your tablecloth.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a stunning silk/wool blend evening dress with sequins and feathers around the bottom. Two drycleaners would not accept it, stating that the feathers might melt or snap off in the drying process. I have sponge cleaned key areas with both water and a silk cleaner after two wears and have washed the synthetic lining by hand, but the dress must be cleaned properly soon. Can feathers be drycleaned? Can you recommend a good drycleaner near the VA/DC border?
Content.description:
Dear Sophie- I would call these dry cleaners in NYC to see if they give you the same answer.
Hallak Cleaners 1232 2nd [64th/65th] Madame Paulette 1255 2nd [65th/66th] 212.838.6827
If you get the same response, I believe you can wash it.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have been trying to find a place that can clean a satin evening purse and matching shoes that are both pal pink and non-dyed. Can I do this myself with your products?
Content.description:
Dear Laila- The shoes are tricky. The best way is to re-dye them as spot treating will most likely leave a water ring around the area.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a gorgeous new white lace dress that I wore last week to a party in Barbados. There are no stains, but it was humid and perhaps some perspiration. How should I clean and store this dress?
Content.description:
Dear Bree- The lace is probably cotton, but it may also be silk or synthetic. Assuming it is a cotton dress, you can use our Wash & Stain Bar to tacking any sweat stains from perspiration. Even if there are no visible stains, it is good to use this bar on effected areas, such as the underarms and collar. Simply wet the bar and apply it directly to the dress.
Next, launder as normal with our Whites Detergent. This detergent has added bleach alternative to help keep the integrity of your whites white! You can also add some All-Purpose Bleach Alternative to the wash for an extra boost of brightening.
For dresses, outerwear and other items that you want to hang, we recommend garment bags from the Container Store. The natural cotton canvas material will allow your items to breathe and work to prevent yellowing. http://www.containerstore.com/shop?productId=10000083&N=&Ns=p_sort_default%7C0&Ntt=canvas+garment+bags
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I need to clean my silk/sateen wedding dress which has marks on the skirt part. Unsure of what caused the marks as they were present when I bought it as a stock item from the rack at the bridal shop. It looks like it could be makeup as it's a small brown mark. I have been told spot treating is not possible as water marks may result. How should I wash it as it has beading on the bust area?
Content.description:
Dear Bronwyn- My best recommendation for this would be to use a professional service that specializes in the cleaning of wedding gowns. I've listed below two contacts that we use and trust.
J. Scheer & Co. is the crme de la crme of service...and price. Specializing in the conservation, cleaning and preservation of fine textiles, they're always reliable.
J. Scheer & Co. 6 East 74th Street New York, NY 10021 (800) 448-7291 www.jscheer.com
We also know our friend Miguel does cleaning and storing of wedding garments. He swears by their value and work with prices that are far more reasonable.
Slate NYC 96 Morton Street, Ground Floor New York, NY 10014 (800) 573-8459 www.slatenyc.com
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Can you give me a recipe to follow in cleaning and preparing my wedding dress for preservation? The dress is made of a high quality polyester satin skirt with a nylon lace bodice. The tule underskirt/petticoat is detachable from the dress. Also, the veil is a delicate antique blusher veil in a navy blue. Cleaning tips on this as well would be helpful. Would be a mistake to store the veil with the dress?
Content.description:
Dear Pama- While we don't launder or preserve wedding gowns, we can definitely refer you to a few places that can help you. I would contact them directly with your questions.
J. Scheer & Co specializes in the conservation, cleaning and preservation of textiles. J. Scheer & Co. 6 East 74th Street New York, NY 10021 (800) 448-7291 www.jscheer.com
Slate NYC is a green dry cleaner. Miguel cleans wedding garments, and Slate's prices are a little more reasonable. Slate NYC 96 Morton Street, Ground Floor New York, NY 10014 (800) 573-8459 www.slatenyc.com
Best- The Laundress

Content.name:
Dear Laundress- I have a small cake stain on my wedding dress, but not much else. I'm a little put off by the "wedding dress" preservationits who charge 120-400$ for cleaning /preserving.
I have been toying with the idea of trying to wash it in our front-loading washing machine on the delicate cycle. What do you guys think?
It is lined, but supposedly the entire dress is 100% silk and the label says "Dry Clean Only". Do you think it would be okay to hand wash it in the bathtub?
Content.description:
Dear Mary Laura- Silk is a very washable fabric, just be sure to remove the black belt first and launder separate if necessary. My best recommendation would be to pretreat the staining with Stain Solution, you can then make a cold water bath with Delicate Wash and allow to soak for 30 minutes.
Rinse well under cold water and press out the water, never wring or twist. Hang or lay flat to dry and steam while damp.
For proper preservation- we recommend storing with acid free tissue and box. These tools can be purchased from Talas, I've linked below contact information.
Talas 330 Morgan Avenue Brooklyn, NY 11211 (212) 219-0770 www.talasonline.com
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I use bleach and detergent at the same time to whiten my laundry. As I understand it, each cancels the other out. Is this really correct?
Content.description:
Dear Ginny- Yes, bleach cancels out detergent and weakens the fibers. Try eliminating the bleach for your wasing equation and see if you notice a difference. Our detergent has optical brighteners which is better for the fibers and has more whitening effects than bleach.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- When and how should I use chlorine bleach to brighten and remove stains from my whites? What are your thoughts about the newer "oxyclean" type of products?
Content.description:
Dear Don- We are not fans of using bleach to achieve whitening properties as it often yellows fabric and makes it frail. Oxyclean can certainly be used for whitening when using hot water, long cycles and soaking. I recommend our All-Purpose Bleach Alternative which is a nontoxic, biodegradable, fragrance-free alternative to bleach. Just add to your wash cycle to whiten and brighten clothing - it's safe for colors!
I also recommend following our Pit Stain recipe to remove stains from your whites.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- When you add bleach in the machine to help whiten shirts, should the water be hot, cold or warm?
Content.description:
Dear Cynthia- We don't recommend using bleach as it can yellow fabrics especially elastic, lycra, spandex and nylon. It also weakens the fabric.
Regarding water temperature, hot water works best. Our Stain Solution, All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and Whites Detergent are saviors when curing dingy whites. Adding a cup of white vinegar will also enhace the brightness of your whites.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I read a newspaper article stating that chlorine bleach and detergent cancel out each other. Should I run the first cycle with just bleach and the next cycle with detergent?
Content.description:
Hi Beth- Bleach and detergent do cancel each other out. If you must use bleach, do run a load first then a second load with detergent. Be careful with the bleach as it will reduce the fabric strength and can yellow nylon, elastic, spandex and linen fabrics. A great bleach alternative is adding our All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and Scented Vinegar to the washing cycle.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Will your S-002 turn my white T-shirt back to shiny white? Also if there is print on the T-shirt, is it safe to use this detergent?
Content.description:
Dear Lisa- Our Whites Detergent has ingredients to do just that. We recommend pre-soaking your item in hot water with Stain Solution, if any specific areas are stained, and Whites Detergent and All-Purpose Bleach Alternative.
There isn't any bleach in our products, so prints or colors won't be damaged. The presoak is only for fabric that is yellowed or discolored. Follow with a machine wash using the Whites Detergent.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress How do I get rid of yellow underarm stains and body odor from white shirts?
Content.description:
Hi Denise- Our detergent should remove the odor from the items in the wash cycle. If that isn't suffiecient however, we recommend a wash cycle with a 1/2 cup of vinegar followed by a wash cycle with Whites Detergent. It is best to use hot water, especially with the vinegar cycle.
As for sweat or pit stains we have a recipe: - Apply Stain Solution directly to the discolored area. - Pour hot water on the area and let soak for an hour or so. I use a kettle and do this process in a rubber bin. - Repeat this process until satisfied. I usually do it two or three times. - End by washing in our Signature or Whites Detergent. - Enjoy your (practically) new garment! ** Please note that this is only suitable for cottons or cotton blends.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Do you have a secret for getting deodorant stains out of white tees? Please enlighten me!
Content.description:
Dear Todd- Absolutely! I am assuming you are referring to yellowing. This is a combination of body oils, prespiratoin and deodorant build up on clothing. To remove these stains, follow our Pit Stain recipe.
If you are speaking about white deotorant marks that get rubbed on you clothes as you are putting them on, you should rub the inside of the fabric against the marked, outside area. The fabric against fabric will remove the marks. This strategy works for me all the time on black dresses and suiting fabric!
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I would love to use white sheets, but I am afraid that they will get that grungy, used look as so many of my white T-shirts have. When I buy sheets, towels, etc., I don't buy a lot, therefore mine get used often.
Content.description:
Dear Paula- We completely understand your reluctance. We love white linens, which is why we developed several great products and tips that work to whiten your whites and keep them that way!
For items you already own, your first step is to presoak. Presoak with white vinegar. Make a warm bath with cup of white vinegar, and let your linens soak for up to an hour.
For stain removal, do a second presoak in hot water with the All-Purpose Bleach Alternative. You can combine with our enzyme based Stain Solution to fight staining.
We use our bleach alternative in every load of white laundry. The bleach alternative is an oxygen bleach that is unscented and color safe. It is a natural stain remover and deodorizer. You can pour it directly into the washing machine with our Whites Detergent to help brighten your towels!
Our Whites Detergent is formulated with enzymes to help keep your white clothes white. This product combines natural bleach alternative and stain fighting agents to lengthen the life of your white fabrics. The combination of the Whites Detergent and bleach alternative works magic!
For older items, do not be discouraged if your whites do not automatically whiten after one wash. We will often treat items a few times before getting optimal results, especially if the discoloration has set in over time. For new items, these techniques will help to ensure that they don't discolor over time.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- My friend has a pillow that has a gray smudge line. She believes it may be newspaper print but has referred to it as something a metal clothing hanger may leave behind. Can you help?
Content.description:
Dear Kim- First check if the pillow has a zipper or if the inner filling is removable. This stain most likely can be removed with Stain Solution and a hand wash. Ink and newspaper are generally not permanent stains.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: The Laundress- Sometimes I notice rust colored stains on my white sheets. Where does that come from?
Content.description:
Chris- Usually the yellow stains are from rust in the water or washing machine. In general, it is helpful to maintain your machine by running an empty, full load with hot water and bleach. This process is also important to do with an anti-rust liquid that you can purchase at a hardware store.
If your machine is brand new, it may be some rust from the water source/pipes. We recommend soaking the spotted area in hot water with our Stain Solution for an hour and repeating the process to lift completely.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have some white towels which are now a dingy grey. I have tried numerous things including borax, vinegar, oxiclean. I've tried some of your stain removal but this didn't seem to help. Is there any hope? These are good towels, Yves DeLorme, and while they are now 9 years old, they are still in good shape! Any comments?
Content.description:
Dear Barb- It sounds like your towels have had a pretty long life! With all of the wear-and-tear, wash cycles, natural body oils, lotions, etc. it's to be expected that the towels would get a little dingy.
To brighten your towels, I suggest soaking them in a basin of hot water mixed with All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and Stain Solution for half an hour. Once the presoak is complete, machine wash in hot water using Whites Detergent. This particular detergent is formulated with surfactants, and stain fighting enzymes to keep your whites clean and bright as new.
To avoid future dinginess, it is best to follow the above treatment on all new towels, rather than waiting until further down the road.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- My husband wears a 100% cotton t-shirt under this dress shirts. Over time, there appears to be a wax-like build-up in the arm-pit area of these cotton t-shirts. The discoloration and wax build-up are both visible and tactile. I'm assuming it's from deodrant gel.
Content.description:
Our Pit Stain recipe addresses this exact problem, however the sticky aspect I am not familiar with. If this method isn't successful please let me know. I suggest switching to a non-gel product to see if the build up reduces. The yellow or grey discoloration is very common and workable.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Is fabric softner necessary with the Wool and Cashmere Shampoo? Also, can white shirts with colored trim, such as a Polo with navy trim, be used with the S-002?
Content.description:
Dear Debbie- Fabric softener isn't necessary - it's merely a personal preference with regular laundry. We do not recommend fabric softener for washing wool and cashmere, however.
Our Whites Detergent doesn't contain bleach so it is perfectly safe to use with colored trims.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- How do I get white fabric with spandex back to the origial bright white shade?
Content.description:
Dear Carrol- As spandex synthetics love to take in and hold odor and stains, it can be tricky to get such garments with these fibers back in true form. The best treatment for whitening these fibers is with our All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and Stain Solution.
Simply apply the Stain Solution directly to the discolored areas, gently work it into the fabric and add sprinkles of Bleach Alternative to make a paste. Next, presoak the item in a basin of hot water with 1 capful of the Bleach Alternative and follow with a regular laundering cycle.
To prevent future dinginess, add 1 capful of the Bleach Alternative with your laundry detergent when machine washing. **Please note that the All-Purpose Bleach Alternative is not to be used on silks or woolens.
For additional tips on how to brighten your whites, please see the link below. Ihttp://blog.thelaundress.com/wordpress/2011/06/13/washing-summer-whites-2/
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Which of your products washes and cares for alpaca sweaters? Most state "Dry Clean Only" and I'm wondering if this can be avoided. How do I wash such items?
Content.description:
Dear Sara- You can wash these items and doing so is actually safer for the garments over time, as dry cleaning chemicals can be harsh and drying.
Laundering with our Wool & Cashmere Shampoo will work to both clean and preserve the natural oils of the yarns. You can pretreat any staining with the Wash & Stain Bar and then launder in the machine with cold water, on a delicate/woolen cycle. You may also wash by hand.
Remove promptly from the machine and lay flat to dry, do not use the dryer. Steaming while damp is best to reduce creasing.
Below is a link to further instructions on caring for wool & cashmere: http://blog.thelaundress.com/wordpress/?s=recipe+washing+wool
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a make-up stain on my lilac cashmere sweater. I not tried to remove the stain, so the sweater has not been washed or dry cleaned yet, worn only once. Should I use Stain Solution plus Wool & Cashmere Shampoo?
Content.description:
Dear Renee- Yes, you can use our Stain Solution and Wool & Cashmere Shampoo to wash your sweater.
Pretreat any staining with our Stain Solution. Make sure to really work it into the fabric. If you choose to launder in the machine, turn the item inside out and place in a mesh bag. Add our Wool & Cashmere Shampoo directly into the drum or detergent dispenser. Make sure the machine is set to the Delicate or Woolen cycle. Most importantly, the water temperature must be cold/cold or risk shrinkage.
You can find more details in the link below: http://blog.thelaundress.com/wordpress/?s=recipe+washing+wool
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- If my cashmere sweaters were previously dry cleaned, can they now be hand washed?
Content.description:
Dear Jacqui- You absolutely can wash wool and cashmere if it was previously dry cleaned. You will be so pleased with the results!
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a cashmere sweater that is light grey and I've thought about dying it a different color. Is this possible? If so, how should I go about it?
Content.description:
Dear Melissa- Have you ever tie dyed? The most common dye out there is RIT which is available in grocery stores, drugstores and craft stores. A company I bought dye from in college is dhamatrading.com.
For color choice, I recommend dying black. I don't know how the other colors will take or if you will get a "heathered" look dying with another color based on the original yarn dye structure.
After dying, wash the sweater alone because dye transfer will most likely occur. Also note in the dying process if it requires boiling or hot water which may shrink your sweater.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- The online description for Wool & Cashmere Shampoo calls for 1/4 cup in the gentle cycle. How many items can I effectively clean with this amount? I I am primarily washing medium and lightweight sweaters.
Content.description:
Dear Marlena- cup is for a full load. If you are only washing a few sweaters at a time, a couple squirts is suitable for a small or medium load.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- What product would you use for black and other dark colored merino wool and cashmere sweaters?
Content.description:
Hi Patricia, We recommend using our Wool & Cashmere Shampoo which is perfect for your sweaters! Just make sure you separate them by color when washing.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- If the care label on a garment says "Dry Clean Only," can I machine wash with your Wool & Cashmere Shampoo?
Content.description:
Hi Jayme, You can machine wash "Dry Clean Only" wool and cashmere on a delicate/gentle cycle. Do not put wool and cashmere in the dryer, however! You can also hand wash.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Is fabric softner necessary with the Wool and Cashmere Shampoo? Also, can white shirts with colored trim, such as a Polo with navy trim, be used with the Whites Detergent?
Content.description:
Dear Debbie- Fabric softener isn't necessary - it's merely a personal preference with regular laundry. We do not recommend fabric softener for washing wool and cashmere, however.
Our Whites Detergent doesn't contain bleach so it is perfectly safe to use with colored trims.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a cashmere dressing gown. The label says "Dry Clean Only," but I don't want to ruin it by dry cleaning. Can I machine wash it? If so, how do I go about washing it? It's a tightly woven cashmere-like fabric.
Content.description:
Dear Dawn- I recommend following our Wool & Cashmere reciple which I've listed below.If your dress has a lining however, you may have to follow different instructions.
Pretreat any stains with Stain Solution and gently work it into the fabric. Follow by hand washing in a bath of cool water and Wool & Cashmere Shampoo, turning the item inside out. Leave to soak for roughly 30 minutes and rinse well. Lay flat in its' natural shape to dry.
We like to steam our cashmere for a perfect finish and spray with Wool & Cashmere Spray between washing and wearing to keep the yarns fresh.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have always washed my wool sweaters, but I now have well water which has a lot of minerals. Is it safe to wash my wool in well water?
Content.description:
Dear Irene- Are you noticing a problem while washing your sweaters with your well water or are you just concerned? Lindsey has well water and our products work brilliantly with it, especially the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo. If you are noticing a problem, I would use distilled water for the soaking process and tap water to rinse.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name:
Dear Laundress- My husband has lots of heavy cashmere sweaters, which I wash in cold water in the machine and seems to work perfectly. I'm never sure what speed of spin I should use. Any thoughts? Also, I wash them often because he always stretches the rib at the bottom and washing is the only way to get it back to size. Do you have any suggestions on this?
Best- The Laundress
Content.description:
Dear Marilyn- The delicate cycle or the lowest spin on your machine is what you want to aim for when washing cashmere. We recommend using a Mesh Washing Bag for delicate items which your husband's thick sweaters are not.
Washing is the best way to get ribbings back to shape. You can do the shortest washing cycle to get the job done.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I can't wait to try your Wool & Cashmere Shampoo and Fabric Conditioner! Can I use the Fabric Conditioner when washing cashmere?
Content.description:
Dear Luanna Mae- We are so glad that you are excited about The Laundress. We do not recommend using Fabric Conditioner with cashmere as it coats the natural softness and oils in cashmere. The only time that I have done this is when I washed rough wool which was otherwise unbearable.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Do you have a product that helps take the itch or scratchiness out of a new cashmere or wool sweater?
Content.description:
Hi Jean, I recommend washing and soaking the scatchy items a few times and see if they soften up as there isn't much else you can do to soften the stiff hairs in the yarn. You could use fabric softener, but it isn't great for the yarns because it puts a smooth coating on the item. If the itchiness is unbearable however, that is an option.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Is the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo safe for use on merino wool?
Content.description:
Dear Cindy- Wool & Cashmere Shampoo is completely safe for merino wool!
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- My wife's cashmere pullovers are getting little holes in the fabric before they are worn. Any ideas what we should be looking for?
Content.description:
Dear Michael- This sounds like a critter epidemic. If you can return the items, do so. I recommend washing all of the items following the wool and cashmere recipe on the site as well as storing all sweaters in cotton bags such as our storage bags. Spraying the Wool & Cashmere Spray is highly recommended as cedar naturally repells bugs and moths.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a big moth problem. I have many cashmere and woolen sweaters many of which now have holes. I was told that I need to clean them in order to insure that the larva are gone. Dry cleaning would be hundreds of dollars. I was wondering if the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo would work and how do you use it.
Content.description:
Dear Bonnie- The Wool & Cashmere Shampoo is certainly the correct product to use for cleaning such garments, however greater measures need to be taken before washing to ensure that the larva are in fact dead. Only under extreme temperatures do such bugs actually die. To effectively treat your clothing and storage spaces, please follow the steps listed below.
Tips for post moth attacks Place infected clothing in airtight bags and freeze for 72 hours - the harsh temperatures will kill any lingering insects Vacuum, dust and wash shelves and floors as moths feed on dust, dirt and body oils Launder all clothing after freezing and cleaning is complete, in this case you should use Wool & Cashmere Shampoo - if you cannot launder at home, we recommend Slate NYC, a green dry cleaning/laundering service (see below for contact information) o For step by step instructions on washing wool and cashmere, please visit the link below: o http://blog.thelaundress.com/wordpress/project/recipe-for-washing-wool-cashmere/ Clean machine after washing infected items Repair holes caused by moths immediately - we recommend Alter Knit for this job (see below for contact information)
Tips for moth prevention Wash all garments at the beginning of a new season and before packing at the end of one Clean drawers for the new season by washing, vacuuming and re-organizing them Place Natural Lavender Sachets and Scented Drawer Sheets in Cedar in drawers and clothing storage units as cedar and lavender are natural moth and bug repellants Spray clothing with the Wool & Cashmere Spray as cedar is a natural moth and bug repellant Store clothing in breathable fabric such as cotton or linen that has a zipper such as the All-Purpose Storage Bag Make sure to never store clothing in plastic or cardboard or in damp/humid areas
Slate NYC 107 Horatio Street New York, NY 10014 (800) 573-8459 www.slatenyc.com
Alter Knit New York 245 W 29th Street, Suite 800 New York, NY 10001 (212) 473-6363 www.alterknitnewyork.com
I've also included a link to our blog post which provides further detail on how to prevent and treat moth infestation in your closets! http://blog.thelaundress.com/wordpress/project/moth-silverfish-bug-prevention-plus-post-moth-care/
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- What is the best way to remove mothball odor from cashmere?
Content.description:
Dear Chad-
Mothball odors can be very difficult to remove. My best recommendation would be to make a bath with tepid water and white vinegar and allow your cashmere to soak for 30 minutes. Our Scented Vinegar works wonders for removing odors from fabrics.
Rinse well, removing all vinegar. You can then make a bath with tepid water and our Wool & Cashmere Shampoo and leave to soak for 30 minutes.
Lay flat to dry- do not use the dryer and steam while damp. I have also linked below our recipe on Washing Wool & Cashmere. In addition, lavender sachets are a more natural alternative to using mothballs; they are just as effective and smell much nicer. http://blog.thelaundress.com/wordpress/?s=recipe+washing+wool
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Can I use the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo on a pashmina shawl? How should I wash and dry it ?
Content.description:
Dear Penelope- Absolutely - they wash beautifully! Follow the Wool & Cashmere recipe to achieve the best results.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- As I collect cashmere, but hate dry-cleaning it, I was excited to discover your product. Some of my cashmere has become "pilled." What is the best way to make my sweaters look new again? I have heard of sweater stones for de-pilling, but am not sure if that is the best. Thanks for any help you can give me!
Content.description:
Dear Nicole- Pilling is one of the downfalls to lovely cashmere. Hand washing helps as well as machine washing with the item inside out. The pilling generally comes from movement of the body such as under the arms, however.
While we are firm believers in the Sweater Stone, the Sweater Comb would be the most apropriate de-pilling device for your fine cashmere.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Can you recommend anyone who can repair a hole in my cashmere sweater?
Content.description:
Dear Sheila- We work with Alter Knit New York. The turn around time is quite lengthy, but her work is good!
We searched long and hard and finally she appeared! The woman we have waited for to mend our souls and cashmeres! Holes, tears, splitting seams, snags and all are splendidly repaired by the artistic weave masters at Alter Knit. They can even alter, shorten, slim, restyle and repurpose woolens and are woven to your request. We will wash and send it to Alter Knit - so fantastic it has been deemed the "sweater rehab."
Alter Knit New York 245 W 29th Street, Suite 800 New York, NY 10001 (212) 473-6363 request@alterknitnewyork.com www.alterknitnewyork.com

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Can I use the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo on sheepskin rugs? The thing to avoid is apparently enzymes that can damage the leather side.
Content.description:
Dear Sandra- You can wash your sheepskin rug with the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo. Machine wash in cold water on a delicate/woolen cycle. Remove promptly from the washer and tumble dry on a low temperature setting for 30 minutes. Allow the rug to finish air drying.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Are you sure washing wool sweaters with Wool & Cashmere Shampoo won't shrink the fibers?
Content.description:
Dear Lynn- Wool should be washed in cool water. Hot water and a hot dryer will shrink the fibers.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name:
Dear Laundress- I have a merino wool sweater that has a printed silk panel on the front. I have your J. Crew Cashmere Wash and your Delicate Wash and was wondering which one I should use to wash the garment. I am concerned about shrinkage and the integrity of the silk.
Also, I have a wool blend skirt and a wool coat, would your Fabric Fresh be a good way to avoid dry cleaning these items? And could I wash them with the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo? They are both lined in acetate.
Content.description:
Dear Natasha- For all three of your items, we recommend washing with the J.Crew Cashmere Wash. Our rule of thumb for blended fabric is to wash according to the highest percentage. i.e. if the item is 70% merino wool and 30% silk, wash with our Wool & Cashmere Shampoo, or J.Crew Cashmere Wash. This detergent is very gentle and will not harm the integrity of the silk paneling on your sweater. It will also work well to launder your wool blend skirt and wool coat!
Pretreat any staining with our Wash & Stain Bar. If you choose to launder in the machine instead of hand washing, place in a Mesh Bag. Add the J.Crew Cashmere Wash directly into the drum or detergent dispenser. Make sure the machine is set to the Delicate or Woolen cycle. Most importantly, the water temperature must be cold/cold or risk shrinkage. I've linked more information below for your convenience. http://blog.thelaundress.com/wordpress/?s=recipe+washing+wool
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a small stain on my wool jacket. Would the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo help to treat the stain?
Content.description:
Dear Dana- Is your jacket lined? You will have to spot clean it with Stain Solution and water. Make sure you work in the solution into the fabric without agitating it too much.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- How do I get perspiration stains out of cashmere? Will your Stain Solution work?
Content.description:
Dear Sandi- I do recommend our Stain Solution. Once pretreated, you should follow the Wool & Cashmere recipe to achieve the best results.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- What is the best cleaning solution for a coffee stain on pure wool knitwear?
Content.description:
Dear Terry- I always get coffee on my sleeves! Just apply Stain Solution on the stain and soak, rinse and repeat until it comes out. Follow with a hand wash in Wool & Cashmere Shampoo and lay flat to dry.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I've heard that drycleaning cashmere strips it of its oil and makes it stiff. Is that true?
Content.description:
Dear Pat- This is indeed true. We recommend caring for your cashmere at home using our Wool and Cashmere recipe listed below:
- Examine for stains: pretreat soiled areas with Stain Solution or the Wash & Stain Bar. Always treat stains first and presoak for most effective removal.
- Machine wash: Change machine setting to woolens/delicate cycle. Make sure water temperature is cold. Add the appropriate amount of Wool & Cashmere Shampoo to the machine. If possible, place in a Mesh Bag to wash.
-Dry/Finish: Lay item flat in its natural shape on a drying rack or towel. Do make place in the dryer. We like to steam our wool/cashmere for the perfect finish. http://blog.thelaundress.com/wordpress/project/recipe-for-washing-wool-cashmere/
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Do your products contain any animal-based ingredients? Do you test your products on animals?
Content.description:
Dear Caroline- We do not test on animals nor use animal ingredients in our products. Each of our products proudly states this fact on its label!
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a old christening gown that is nearly 40 years old. It's yellowing and rusty-looking. I tried bleaching it, but the color stays the same. How can I make it white again?
Content.description:
Dear Gail- I am not surprised the bleach didn't work well, as bleach doesn't usually remove stains like these. I've listed some stain removal methods below:
- Apply Stain Solution directly to any particularly tough rust-like spots and gently work it into the fabric. For extra tough stains, sprinkle All-Purpose Bleach Alternative into the Stain Solution to create a powerful cleaning paste. - Machine wash using Whites Detergent. - Line dry in the sun or lay flat in its natural shape to dry.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Do you have any recommendations on which products to use for someone with eczema or other skin conditions?
Content.description:
Dear Uhuru- Thank you for reaching out. There are no known allergens in our products and they are all gentle and safe to use against skin. The Baby Detergent is especially effective in this scenario!
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- What ingredients are in the Crease Release? I have sensitive skin and need to know before I purchase it!
Content.description:
Dear Elle- The active ingredient in the Crease Release is silicone, which works to relax the fibers. The Crease Release should be sprayed directly onto the fabric, not to the skin.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I am interested in your products, but am concerned about the environment. How do your products stand up environmentally?
Content.description:
Dear Jean- We at The Laundress are also concerned about the environment, therefore we don't use any dyes in our products or test on animals. Our products are also 100% bio-degradable and are both allergen-free and gluten-free.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a christening gown that is 27 years old. The care label on the slip says it's made of acrylic, but the dress appears to be nylon. After all these years, the articles have yellowed. What is your suggested method to whiten them without destroying the fabric?
Content.description:
Dear Dianne- Do not use bleach as it will further yellow nylon and acrylic. These fabrics can withstand heat, so I suggest boiling the gown in a large pot of water with a cup of white vinegar and treating the stained areas with Stain Solution and All-Purpose Bleach Alternative. Once this pretreat is complete, I recommend machine washing with the Whites Detergent on a delicate or hand washing cycle.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I just found a vintage, organdy christening dress. I believe it's 60 years old. It's in perfect shape except for discoloration - it's very yellow. How do I get the color brightened and whitened?
Content.description:
Dear Donna- If the dress is a cotton organdy: - Apply Stain Solution directly to any stained areas and gently work it into the fabric. When dealing with more difficult stains, sprinkle some All-Purpose Bleach Alternative onto the Stain Solution to create a powerful cleaning paste. Put the gown in a boiling pot of water, adding a cup of whie vinegar to the bath. Turn off the heat and leave to soak. - Finish with a hand wash using the Whites Detergent.
*Do not bleach as this will make the yellowing worse!
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Do you have any recommendations on which products to use for someone with eczema or other skin conditions?
Content.description:
Dear Uhuru- Thank you for reaching out. There are no known allergens in our products and they are all gentle and safe to use against skin. The Baby Detergent is especially effective in this scenario!
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I need help cleaning my linen/cotton drapes. The label says "Dry Clean Only," but the dry cleaner tells me that I need to accept the risk that the drapes may stain when exposed to sunlight because of the dry cleaning chemicals. The linen facing is 55% linen/45% cotton and the lining is 100% cotton. Should I accept the dry cleaning risk, or risk washing the drapes in washing machine?
Content.description:
Dear Emma- Linen and cotton are the most washable fabrics and are best cleaned when washed. The concern with laundering, especially with drapery, is shrinkage and stretching. If the goods were not prewashed, there is a good chance the length may change.
It is a tricky situation- the dry cleaning process generally has less shrinkage, but has other negative effects. Laundering may have length issues. For minimal shrinkage, wash in cold water with low agitation or on the delicate cycle, and lay flat to dry. Do not put the drapes in the dryer or hang them as you do not want them to elongate if stressed. Press while damp to achieve the best results.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- My carpet has stains from my dog's urine. I have had the carpet cleaned many times and the stains still come back. What should I do?
Content.description:
Dear Mary- The first process is to take a liquid detergent directly onto the stain with a sponge. I recommend our Stain Solution because of its high percentage of enzymes which you will need for proper removal. Treat the affected area with a sponge and scrub after letting the detergent soak for a half hour. Finish by removing excess detergent with a dry clothe or sponge. This process may need to be repeated a few times.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Will your Whites Detergent turn my white T-shirt white again? If there is print on the T-shirt, is it safe to use this detergent?
Content.description:
Dear Lisa- Our Whites Detergent has ingredients to do just that. We recommend presoaking your item in hot water with Stain Solution, if any specific areas are stained, and Whites Detergent and All-Purpose Bleach Alternative.
There isn't any bleach in our products, so prints or colors won't be damaged. The presoak is only for fabric that is yellowed or discolored. Follow with a machine wash using the Whites Detergent.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- My husband wears a 100% cotton t-shirt under this dress shirts. Over time, there appears to be a wax-like build-up in the arm-pit area of these cotton t-shirts. The discoloration and wax build-up are both visible and tactile. I'm assuming it's from deodorant gel.
Content.description:
Dear Elizabeth- The sticky aspect I am not familiar with - I suggest switching to a non-gel product to see if the build up reduces. The yellow or grey discoloration is very common and workable and can be combated using our "Pit Stain" recipe listed below:
Pretreat: Apply Stain Solution directly to the soiled areas and sprinkle All-Purpose Bleach Alternative onto the solution. Gently work this powerful cleaning paste into the fabric. For added cleaning power, pour hot water from a height onto the area. Follow by soaking the sweater in a bath of hot water and a capful of All-Purpose Bleach Alternative for roughly 30 minutes. If the stains aren't removed after the first attempt, you may need to repeat the pretreat process.
Wash: Machine wash as normal using either the Whites Detergent or Signature Detergent and hot water.
Dry: Do not dry until all stains have been removed. Once removed, dry as normal.
For further information on how to combat set-in stains, visit our blog post below: http://blog.thelaundress.com/wordpress/project/recipe-for-pit-stain-removal/
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- What do you suggest for caring for fine colored linen napkins?
Content.description:
Dear Nancy- Linen is actually very easy to launder. Pretreat any stains with our Wash & Stain Bar, and launder as normal! All of our products are color safe, so I'd suggest using our Signature in the washing machine with warm/hot water. I've included our Can I Be Washed? chart, for your convenience. It goes into a little more detail on how to wash specific fabrics, like linen. http://blog.thelaundress.com/wordpress/can-i-be-washed/
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a stunning silk/wool blend evening dress with sequins and feathers around the bottom. Two drycleaners would not accept it, stating that the feathers might melt or snap off in the drying process. I have sponge cleaned key areas with both water and a silk cleaner after two wears and have washed the synthetic lining by hand, but the dress must be cleaned properly soon. Can feathers be drycleaned? Can you recommend a good drycleaner near the VA/DC border?
Content.description:
Dear Sophie- I would call these dry cleaners in NYC to see if they give you the same answer.
Hallak Cleaners 1232 2nd [64th/65th]
Madame Paulette 1255 2nd [65th/66th] 212.838.6827
If you get the same response, I believe you can wash it.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have been trying to find a place that can clean a satin evening purse and matching shoes that are both pal pink and non-dyed. Can I do this myself with your products?
Content.description:
Dear Laila- The shoes are tricky. The best way is to re-dye them as spot treating will most likely leave a water ring around the area.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a gorgeous new white lace dress that I wore last week to a party in Barbados. There are no stains, but it was humid and perhaps some perspiration. How should I clean and store this dress?
Content.description:
Dear Bree- The lace is probably cotton, but it may also be silk or synthetic. Assuming it is a cotton dress, you can use our Wash & Stain Bar to tacking any sweat stains from perspiration. Even if there are no visible stains, it is good to use this bar on effected areas, such as the underarms and collar. Simply wet the bar and apply it directly to the dress.
Next, launder as normal with our Whites Detergent. This detergent has added bleach alternative to help keep the integrity of your whites white! You can also add some All-Purpose Bleach Alternative to the wash for an extra boost of brightening.
For dresses, outerwear and other items that you want to hang, we recommend garment bags from the Container Store. The natural cotton canvas material will allow your items to breathe and work to prevent yellowing. http://www.containerstore.com/shop?productId=10000083&N=&Ns=p_sort_default%7C0&Ntt=canvas+garment+bags
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I need to clean my silk/sateen wedding dress which has marks on the skirt part. Unsure of what caused the marks as they were present when I bought it as a stock item from the rack at the bridal shop. It looks like it could be makeup as it's a small brown mark. I have been told spot treating is not possible as water marks may result. How should I wash it as it has beading on the bust area?
Content.description:
Dear Bronwyn- My best recommendation for this would be to use a professional service that specializes in the cleaning of wedding gowns. I've listed below two contacts that we use and trust.
J. Scheer & Co. is the crme de la crme of service...and price. Specializing in the conservation, cleaning and preservation of fine textiles, they're always reliable.
J. Scheer & Co. 6 East 74th Street New York, NY 10021 (800) 448-7291 www.jscheer.com
We also know our friend Miguel does cleaning and storing of wedding garments. He swears by their value and work with prices that are far more reasonable.
Slate NYC 96 Morton Street, Ground Floor New York, NY 10014 (800) 573-8459 www.slatenyc.com
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: I recently bought a black wool dress. Unfortunately after the first wear, my deodorant left unsightly marks in the armpit area. What is the best way to remove these marks?
Content.description:
Hi Mary,
Thank you for reaching out to us with your laundering questions! To remove the deodorant stains from your wool dress, please follow the instructions below:
Pretreat: Lather the Wash & Stain Bar with cool or tepid water and gently work it into the stained areas. For added cleaning power, put the affected area under the faucet and let the water pressure work into the stain. Follow by soaking the dress in a bath of cool water for up to 30 minutes. If the stain is not completely gone by the end of the soak, you may need to repeat this process.
Wash: Machine wash using the appropriate amount of Wool & Cashmere Shampoo. Make sure to select the delicate/woolens cycle on your machine and wash in cold water.
Dry: Place the dress on top of a towel making sure they are both flat and in their original shape. Roll up the dress in the towel to remove excess water. Lay the dress flat in its natural shape to dry.
For more information on how to care for your wool clothing, please see our blog post below. http://www.thelaundress.com/wordpress/?s=recipe+washing+wool
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I recently purchased linen tablecloths that I am now terrified to use for fear of butter splattering all over. How/what should I do when this occurs to minimize the damage?
Content.description:
Dear Amy-
Linen is very strong and highly washable like cotton, so if they happen to get stained by butter it's easily treatable! Whenever you notice a stain on your linen tablecloth, apply the Stain Solution directly to the affected area. If the stain is larger and more resistant, you can strengthen the formula by sprinkling our All-Purpose Bleach Alternative into the Stain Solution and mixing the two to create a paste. As noted before, apply the mixture directly to the stain and gently work it into the fabric.
Once you've completed the spot treatment, soak your linens in a bath of hot water for 30 minutes. If the stain is not completely gone, you may need to repeat this process until satisfied. When satisfied with the stain removal, launder your linens with the Signature or Whites Detergent which combines color guard and optical brightener to leave your linens looking extra fresh and white!
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- The care label on my 100% acrylic throw from Pottery Barn says "Dry Clean Recommended." Can I machine wash on gentle without ruining it?
Content.description:
Dear Beth-
Thank you for reaching out. You can try laundering your throw with Delicate Wash in cold water. Pretreat any stains with the Wash & Stain Bar and follow by machine washing on a delicate/woolen cycle.
Remove promptly from the machine and lay flat to dry. To reduce creasing, we recommend pressing with a cool iron while damp. Avoid the dryer as increased heat can discolor acrylic fibers.
I hope this information is of help to you.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- How can I remove yellow from white dish towels?
Content.description:
Dear Betty- My best recommendation would be to add 2 capfuls of All-Purpose Bleach Alternative to a wash load using Whites Detergent and hot water. If there are any particular stains that need treated, apply Stain Solution directly to the soiled area and gently work it into the fabric before washing. To prevent future yellowing, add bleach alternative to each wash cycle.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Any guidance on cleaning a stuffed animal that is slept with every night, but is not machine washable
Content.description:
Dear Bonnie- My best recommendation would be to hand wash in warm water with either the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo, Baby Detergent or Signature Detergent. You can try machine washing the stuffed animals as well, inserting them into a Mesh Bag to wash. The Mesh Bag will help protect the stuffed animals from tangling or snagging in the machine.
To dry, leave the stuffed animal in the Mesh Bag and dry in the dryer.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a beautiful cashmere dress that was made for me, but is too long. Is there a way to hand wash it to shrink it a size? Wondering if you have any tips. I was thinking about washing it in warm to tepid water.
Content.description:
Dear Nancy- Hand washing in warm water or applying agitation to the water with your hands will certainly help shrink cashmere. The only issue is that you can't really control how much the dress will shrink or where it happens. My best recommendation would be to have the dress altered - our go-to place is Alter Knit New York. I've listed their contact information below:
Alter Knit New York 245 W 29th Street, Suite 800 New York, NY 10001 (212) 473-6363 www.alterknitnewyork.com
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- My couch has unsightly pilling. The material is a linen type of weave. What is the best item to remove the pills?
Content.description:
Dear Jennifer- To remove that unsightly pilling from your linen couch, I recommend the Sweater Comb. Its fine mesh screens gently pick up stray pills while leaving renewed yarns behind.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have inherited a gorgeous vintage 12 napkin and 120" long Liddell Damask table set that dates back to the 1940's-never used. The box label says ' Finest Egyptian Cotton and Acetate-Made in Ireland.' Dare I try washing these at home with some of your products? There are no cleaners in my small town that specialize in vintage things so I'm a bit concerned.
Content.description:
Dear Louise- As cotton and acetate are very washable fabrics, you can certainly care for these items at home. I recommend machine washing your table set in hot water on the delicate cycle with either the Whites Detergent or Signature Detergent, depending upon the color of the pieces. If any yellowing has occurred, add 2 capfuls of All-Purpose Bleach Alternative to the wash load. Please note that the bleach alternative is color safe, but should not be used on any silks, wools or leathers. Hang all items to dry.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- My dry cleaner wants to charge an arm and a leg to clean the water stain from the bottom of a cotton velvet curtain panel. Is it possible to clean at home? The curtain is about 2 years old.
Content.description:
Dear Vikki- Luckily because your curtain is a cotton velvet, it should be safe to either machine wash or hand wash. By following the steps below, you should be able to treat your item at home and avoid a trip to the dry cleaner!
Pretreat: Apply Stain Solution directly to the mark and gently work it into the fabric. For added cleaning power, hold the soiled area under the faucet and let the lukewarm water help work the solution into the fabric.
Wash: Hand wash in a bath of cool water and Signature Detergent or Delicate Wash, leaving to soak for 30 minutes. You can try machine washing as well, choosing cold water and either of the previously mentioned detergents. Make sure to select the delicate cycle if machine washing.
Dry: Gently press out the water and lay in its natural shape to dry. As velvet cannot be ironed, you may need to steam to finish depending on how the curtain looks when dry.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- We have a new puppy in the house, and that also comes with new stains like grease on a white Kilim from chewing bones. The rug was pretreated by the professional cleaner. What do you suggest to use on the stains? Furthermore, while the pup is potty trained, sometimes it still goes wrong in the house. Is there something we can use on these stains? Our rugs are primarily wool.
Content.description:
Dear Christiane- To help remove the pet messes from your rug, I recommend treating it with the Wash & Stain Bar. To use, simply lather it with water and gently work it into the fabric. You can apply Scented Vinegar to the area in conjunction with the Wash & Stain Bar. To remove the suds, wet a Lint-Free Cleaning Cloth and dab the area clean. If your rug is wool, the stain should lift fairly easily. If the rug is cotton, you should test a small area of it before fully treating the stains as such treatments may leave a wet/treated mark. If the stains aren't removed after the first attempt, you may need to repeat this process.
Sprinkling the All-Purpose Bleach Alternative and vacuuming up the beads will also help deodorize.
I hope this information is of help to you. If you have any further questions, please let me know.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a suede-trim cashmere blanket. Does it have to dry cleaned as the label suggests and are there any special instructions for the suede trim? Also, do you recommend the Sweater Comb or Sweater Stone for this blanket to keep it fluffy?
Content.description:
Dear Kevin- Gwen, our founder, washes her suede-trimmed Ralph Lauren blanket all the time, so yours should be safe to care for at home as well! Simply follow our recipe for washing wool and cashmere to achieve the best results.
Pretreat: Apply Stain Solution directly to any soiled areas and gently work it into the fabric. For added cleaning power, hold the soiled area under the faucet running tepid water to further help work in the solution.
Wash: Machine wash on the delicate/woolens cycle in cold water with Wool & Cashmere Shampoo.
Dry: Press out the water and lay flat in its natural shape to dry.
Tips: Brush with the Cashmere Brush between washes to rejuvenate the yarns and keep your blanket feeling fluffy. Spritz with our Wool & Cashmere Spray for added fragrance.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Johanne- I was wondering what I can do to help care for my husband's fine wool suits and sports jackets. I dry clean them once in a while, but I know the process damages the fiber over time. I own the jiffy steamer.
Content.description:
Dear Johanne- When caring for your husband's wool suits and sport jacket, you're on the right track! Steaming regularly will help keep yarns fresh and crease-free between cleanings. You can also spray the garments with Fabric Fresh with each wear for added fragrance. Our Wool & Cashmere Spray would work perfectly in this instance and it is a more unisex scent as it is scented in a cedar blend. Brushing the suits with either the Pet & Lint Brush or Clothing & Upholstery Brush will help rid the clothing of any lint, hair or excess yarns clinging to the fabric.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Do you have any tips on how to wash clothes labeled "Dry Clean" without the luxury of a washing machine? The video that you have is only for silk, but how about in general?
Content.description:
Dear Althea- The proper care of garments depends upon the fabric content, so washing instructions will different according to each pieces' composition. Generally speaking, when washing garments labeled "Dry Clean" you should hand wash in a basin of cool/cold water using Delicate Wash. The video on washing lingerie is a great example of this process. While I recommend Delicate Wash when treating garments labeled "Dry Clean," each of our products is formulated for both hand and machine washing.
Before washing garments labeled "Dry Clean," please keep in mind that viscose, rayon, polyamide, leather labeled not washable, fur with skin, items with padding and interfacing and items with manufactured pleating should not be washed. For items that are questionable, it is always best to perform a test for water reactions. Simply dip an obscure area of the garment, such as a hem or seam, and submerge it in warm water. If you don't notice any tightening, shrinking, stretching, warping or ripples, your item should be safe to wash!
Below I've listed some general steps on how to care for delicate/dry clean pieces.
Pretreat: - Examine for stains: Pretreat with Stain Solution or Wash & Stain Bar. Always treat stains first and presoak for most effective removal.
Hand washing: - To wash - submerge item(s) in a cool water bath with the appropriate amount of Delicate Wash. - Use your hands to agitate the water and detergent. - Soak for hour (do not soak silk for longer).* - Rinse well - running room temperature water until soapy water is gone. - Do not wring; press the water out of the item instead. *DO NOT PANIC if you see color in the water. This is normal and it is simply the yarn dye releasing color. You will not notice any loss of color at the end.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Help! I have several t-shirts that are in great shape, but they smell rancid no matter how many times they're washed. This happens to my sheets too. Do you have anything that can take the smell out and keep it from coming back?
Content.description:
Dear Lisa- My best recommendation would be to soak your T-shirts and sheets in a basin of hot water mixed with our All-Purpose Bleach Alternative for roughly 30 minutes. As the bleach alternative is a chlorine-free oxygen bleach, it is safe to use on both white and colored pieces. For extreme cases, you can add Scented Vinegar to the mix. Once the soak is complete, machine wash the items in warm water with the appropriate detergent: Whites Detergent, Darks Detergent or Signature Detergent.
To keep garments and sheets fresh between washes, you can spritz with any of our fabric sprays for added fragrance. My favorites are the Delicate Spray, Fabric Fresh Baby and Fabric Fresh Classic.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I was hoping that you could suggest a way to return towels to their original softness. I have a feeling that it may be the detergent I am using.
Content.description:
Dear Allison- Using the wrong detergent can definitely play a factor in the loss of softness in your clothing and towels. Detergents that are low or non-enzyme products tend to be ineffective in this department. If you have hard water, this may be a contributor as well.
To regain softness, you can add fabric softener, such as our Fabric Conditioner, to the wash cycle. The Fabric Conditioner will also help reduce static and leave your towels with that freshly laundered scent! You can also try adding a cup of white vinegar directly to the washing machine drum and run a wash cycle using no detergent or softener then wash again as normal. Our Scented Vinegar is perfect for such an occasion. Using our detergents regularly will also help retain fiber softness because each is plant-based and has high concentrations of enzymes.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have suits from Ann Taylor that are lined. The fabric is 50% polyester, 48% wool, and 2% spandex and the lining is 100% polyester. Can these be washed using your directions for synthetics?
Content.description:
Dear Nora- When caring for your Ann Taylor jackets and pants, we recommend following our recipe for washing wool and cashmere. We suggest this process as items that contain any amount of wool or cashmere should be treated as such.
Pretreat: Pretreat any stains with Stain Solution or the Wash & Stain Bar, applying both directly to the soiled area. We recommend pretreating the underarms, collar and cuffs each time your wash.
Wash: Turn the item inside out and hand wash in a bath of cool water with the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo, leaving it to soak for at least an hour. Rinse until soapy water is gone.
Dry: Turn the item right side out and hang to dry. Make certain to steam while damp to prevent any creasing or wrinkling.
Additional Care: Freshen your suits in between wearing and washing with Wool & Cashmere Spray. Scented in cedar, this spray naturally repels moths and bugs. Steaming regularly between washes will also help keep the yarns of your suits clean and crease-free.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a beaded, silk blouse that says it should only be spot cleaned and there are water marks that I would like to remove. I have the Delicate Wash and was wondering if I can use it to hand wash. Could you please help?
Content.description:
Dear Ana- If your blouse is 100% silk, it should be safe to hand wash with Delicate Wash. Simply pretreat stains with Stain Solution, gently working the solution into the fabric. Follow by hand washing in a bath of cool water with Delicate Wash, leaving to soak for no longer than 30 minutes. Rinse well and lay flat to dry. For best results, you may need to steam the garment while damp.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I'm a college student and use the public washing machines. Can I use your All-Purpose Bleach Alternative mixed with detergent to sanitize a public washing machine without damaging my clothing?
Content.description:
Dear Zhu- Ideally you would want to run an empty load with hot water using Scented Vinegar and All-Purpose Bleach Alternative. Given the circumstances, however, adding the All-Purpose Bleach Alternative to your wash cycle will help to disinfect the machine as well. Please note that the bleach alternative is color-safe and can be used on both your whites and darks! Just make sure to not use this product on silk, wool or leather items.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- How do you machine wash and dry a ski jacket? I have a Bogner jacket and don't want to ruin it since they cost quite a bit. It's 80% down, 80% feather and has a 100% polyester shell. It says to use easy-care detergent and machine wash at 30 and dry at least 2 times. The label says no dry cleaning, but I dry cleaned once already last ski season (whoops)! Just wondering any tips on the cleaning process for this type of jacket.
Content.description:
Dear Daniela- We suggest using the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo when washing down jackets. By following the steps below, you can safely care for your beloved ski gear at home!
Pretreat: Any stains with the Stain Solution. Apply it directly to the stain and gently work it into the fabric.
Wash: Machine wash on the delicate/woolens cycle with cold water adding the appropriate amount of Wool & Cashmere Shampoo.
Dry: Dry in your dryer on low heat and the low tumble cycle, adding clean tennis balls to help fluff up the down filing.
Tips: Steaming your coat between washes will remove mites and allergens, while spraying with Wool & Cashmere Spray will help it stay fresh with its anti-bacterial properties.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I recently found a bottle of your product in my home that was hidden for way too long! I definitely stored it in the wrong place. I was wondering if it's still safe to use if labeled 03/01/2009.
Content.description:
Dear Nancy- As we only use natural ingredients in our detergents, your product is still safe to use and should work just as effectively.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Can you stretch cashmere once it has shrunk?
Content.description:
Dear Bobbi- Unfortunately, shrinkage is permanent. To prevent the shrinking of your cashmere in the future, be sure to avoid all heat during the washing process. When machine washing, be sure to choose cold water and the delicate/woolen cycle as this typically suggests little or no agitation. If you are unable to adjust the settings on your machine, you should hand wash your cashmere items in cold water. When drying, lay flat in its natural shape, never place in the dryer.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I'm a vintage collector and have A LOT of head scarves of various different fabrics. Most of these are rayon, silk, nylon and polyester or a combination of fabrics. I'm wondering if it's possible to hand wash them all together using Delicate Wash, or whether I need to treat some of them differently. I'm not sure what to do with the chiffon scarves that I have.
Content.description:
Dear Kirsten- Luckily, scarves are easy to care for. You can hand wash your scarves in Delicate Wash which is safe for a multitude of fabrics including silk, rayon, nylon, ramie and acetate. When washing, make sure to wash by color groups in case any color release occurs. If the water discolors because of dirt or color release, you will need to refresh the bath and/or wash the scarves one after the other as needed.
As chiffon is typically made of silk, nylon or rayon, washing with the Delicate Wash would be appropriate.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Can the Delicate Wash be used for fine swimwear?
Content.description:
Dear Julie- When washing swimwear, we generally recommend using the Sport Detergent as it is formulated to remove perspiration, body oils, odor and stains from nylon, spandex, cotton and synthetics. If your swimwear is made of finer, more delicate fabrics, however, then hand washing with the Delicate Wash should be sufficient.
We also like to use the Wash & Stain Bar on women's swimwear to clean the straps and underwire, especially when the wearer uses sunscreen which can be difficult to remove.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Which detergent do you recommend for washing my down pillows? Do you have any other tips for how to wash a down pillow - not pillowcases, but the actual pillow?
Content.description:
Dear Lisa- You are not alone in wondering how to wash a down pillow. This is a question we hear quite often! For best results, machine wash down pillows with the Wool & Cashmere Shampoo on the delicate/woolens cycle and use the dryer to dry, tumble and fluff. To ensure that the feathers don't clump while drying, consider adding a clean sneaker or tennis ball to bounce the pillow and redistribute the feathers.
Another cleaning tip is to steam your pillows between washes, which kills 98% of bacteria and mites and helps keep your pillows allergen-free. Fluff and spray with the Wool & Cashmere Spray when making the bed to freshen your pillows.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I spilled balsamic vinegar on my mothers beautiful double cotton knit tablecloth. It just happened at thanksgiving dinner. Can you please tell me how to get this dark stain out.
Content.description:
Dear Cathy- We know how disheartening oil and salad dressing stains can be, but no worries, we remove these types of stains all the time!
By following the steps below you'll be able to restore your mother's tablecloth back to perfect condition!
Pretreat: Apply Stain Solution and soak in a bath of hot water for 30 minutes. It should be fine with the Stain Solution, however if it is more stubborn, mix a sprinkle of the All-Purpose Bleach Alternative in with the Stain Solution to create a paste and soak. If the stain is not completely removed, you may have to repeat the pretreating process until satisfied.
Wash: Machine wash with the Signature Detergent or Whites Detergent in hot water on its normal cycle. We recommend washing it in a large Mesh Bag to protect the knit.
Dry: Use dryer at high temperature or hang to dry only when the stain is removed.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- My Lafayette 148 jacket that's 72% cotton, 22% polyamide has a greasy food stain on it. Can I wash it even though it has a shiny finish and says "Dry Clean"? It has never been cleaned and I'm very hesitant.
Content.description:
Dear Phyllis- Your Lafayette 148 jacket should be safe to wash. As we have had some unfortunate circumstances when washing polyamide/viscose blends, we suggest doing a water test before fully washing. Simply dip a corner of the garment in warm water and see if the fibers get weird or tight. The result will be a good indication of water reaction.
If your jacket looks OK, you can proceed with the steps below:
Pretreat: Lather the Wash & Stain Bar in warm water and gently work it into the stained fabric. Follow by soaking the item in a bath of lukewarm water for no longer than 30 minutes. If the stain is not completely removed, you may have to repeat the pretreating process until satisfied.
Wash: Hand wash in a bath of cool water with the Signature Detergent and let it soak for 30 minutes. Rinse until soapy water is gone and press the water out of the item - do not wring it. - If machine washing, wash with the Signature Detergent, selecting the delicate cycle and cold water. Turn the item inside out and place in a Mesh Bag before washing to protect the button and hardware from snagging or damaging in the wash.
Dry: Lay flat in natural shape or hang to dry.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a Burberry Trench that desperately needs laundered. It is 100% polyester with 100% cupro lining. The care label says "Specialist Dry Clean Only". It instructs to remove all buttons and garment accessories before cleaning. I appreciate any help!
Content.description:
Dear Melanie- We successfully wash Burberry trench coats all of the time. Hopefully the laundering steps below will help get your trench looking as good as new!
Pretreat: Any stained areas with Stain Solution or the Wash & Stain Bar. Apply and gently work it into the stained areas. Follow by soaking the coat in a bath of lukewarm water for a maximum of 30 minutes. If the stains are not completely gone, you may need to repeat the pretreating process until satisfied.
Wash: Machine wash the coat with Signature Detergent, selecting the delicate cycle and cold water. Place the item in a Mesh Bag before washing to protect the buttons and other hardware from snagging or damaging in the machine.
Dry: Lay flat or hang to dry in natural shape
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- Just bought a Maytag HE frontload washer, and am trying to figure out how to use All-Purpose Bleach Alternative with Whites Detergent. The soap compartment is set up to use either liquid or powder. Should I just put the bleach directly into the cylinder with the clothing, and load the liquid soap in the dispenser compartment as normal?
Content.description:
Dear Paul- This is correct. When using the All-Purpose Bleach Alternative, you should add it to the drum of your frontload washer while putting the detergent in the dispenser compartment.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I have a 100% cotton Jil Sander white blouse that says "Do Not Wash" "Professionally Dry Clean". Does this mean that it will be damaged by washing? It's not a complex design, but has simple lines. Is it dry clean because the fabric hasn't been preshrunk?
Content.description:
Dear Linda- Since cotton is an extremely washable fabric and tends to be preshrunk, your Jil Sander blouse should be safe to hand wash. To achieve the best results, hand wash your blouse with the Delicate Wash or Signature Detergent - any water temperature is appropriate. Let the item soak for roughly 30 minutes. Once the blouse has been washed, you can either lay it flat on a drying rack or line dry.
Best- The Laundress

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I LOVE cashmere and stopped taking them to the dry cleaners years ago. Is it true that if a garment's label says "Dry Clean Only" vs. "Dry Cleaning Recommended" that you have to send it to the dry cleaners?
Content.description:
Dear Susan- A lot of our "dry clean only" items are actually washable. We wash woolens and cashmere all the time! However, it is important to follow our washing instructions in order to preserve the quality of the garment.
You can either hand was or machine wash your items with our Wool & Cashmere Shampoo. Make sure you put it on the delicate or woolen cycle--or hand wash cycle, if you don't have woolen or delicate. The water must be cold, or risk shrinkage.
You can wash sweaters together only if they are the same color. Blacks with blacks; reds with reds; pinks with pinks, etc. We never suggest washing different colors together, as they will bleed onto one another. If you do wish to wash a few together, separate them in different Mesh Bags. This helps to prevent any pulling or stretching.
For best results, we suggest steaming your sweaters while damp. This works best to remove wrinkles.
Best- The Laundress
Content.category: Dry Clean vs. Dry Clean Only

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I practice hot yoga and have some Lululemon pieces that have a bit of an odor even after using your amazing Sport Detergent. Is it safe to soak Lululemon in Scented Vinegar? If yes, how would you suggest doing so?
Content.description:
Dear Carin, Thank you for reaching out. Scented Vinegar is actually our recommended product for removing difficult odors from active wear. Simply create a bath of cool water and 2 capfuls of Scented Vinegar and allow to soak for no longer than 30 minutes. At the soak's completion, proceed by laundering as normal.
For additional tips on caring for active wear, please reference our "How Tos" post linked below: http://blog.thelaundress.com/wordpress/2014/06/25/product-spotlight-sport-detergent-sport-spray/

Content.name: Dear Laundress- I'm having trouble folding my fitted sheets neatly. Do you have any suggestions for properly doing so?
Content.description:
Dear Dan- How to fold a fitted sheet is quite a common question! Luckily, we've mastered the art and have the steps listed for you below:
Step 1: Turn the sheet inside out so that the corner seams are showing.
Step 2: Pick up the sheet and hold it so that the longest part of the sheet is horizontal to the floor.
Step 3: Put your hands inside the two fitted corners you are holding so that you're wearing them like mittens.
Step 4: Bring your "mitten" sheet hands together and fold one over the other. You will be peeling off one of your "mittens" and folding it around the other one.)
Step 5: Follow the hem of the sheet down to the next corner, pick it up, and tuck it into the "mitten" corner you've been holding.
Step 6: Do the same with the final corner.
Step 7: Shake to straighten, then lay it down and smooth out the wrinkles.
Step 8: Fold it over onto itself 3-4 times.
Step 9: Fold it again 3-4 times the other, and you're done!
Best-
The Laundress

Content.name: How should I seasonally store my white clothing in the closet to prevent yellowing?
Content.description:
Dear Taurus,
Thank you for reaching out. The best way to store clothing between seasons is to do so in a breathable fabric (cotton or linen) enclosure with a zipper. Our All-Purpose Storage Bag is perfect for this purpose. Items should be stored in a cool, dark and dry area as extreme temperatures will damage textiles and direct sunlight will fade and deteriorate fabrics.
Happy Laundering -The Laundress

Content.name: Hello Gwen & Lindsey, I bought a The Laundress Ironing board cover a year ago. I love it and want to clean it. There are brownish stains from what looks like burn dust from the iron. How can I remove the burn stains with out ruining the cover?
Content.description:
Dear Jessica, Thank you for reaching out. Unfortunately, laundering the cover will diminish the scorch proofing. To remove the present stains, you can try spot treating with Stain Solution.
